Awesome — you're already sitting on a strong foundation. Here's a quick summary of your project based on the proposal and requirements:

🔥 Project Title:

Predicting Energy Prices Using a Multimodal Machine Learning Approach

✅ You're Doing Option 2: The AI Innovation Lab – Multi-Modal Mastery

Which means your project must:

  • Use at least two data types (e.g., time series + text).

  • Train and compare unimodal vs. multimodal models.

  • Include a GitHub repo with documentation.

  • (Bonus) Use MLOps to track models/pipelines.

🧠 Your Concept:

You’re predicting energy prices by integrating:

  • 📈 Time Series Data: historical prices, fuel costs, renewable energy production, and consumption trends.

🛠️ Your Tools / Methods:

  • XGBoost and ARIMA for time series forecasting.

Let’s break down what you’ll need to get done by Monday:

  • Train:

    • XGBoost or ARIMA on time series

🔀 3. Multimodal Fusion

  • Merge predictions from both models

  • Use stacking, weighted average, or simple ensemble

You said:
So I got some energy data about germany, renewable energy production both wind and solar from 2015 till 2020 and the irradiance at that time (at country level), I also have where the renewable energy sites are. There's also a column about energy price prediction for the next day/day (can I use that as a reference about the energy price of that day?). What can I do now
ChatGPT said:

Nice! You’ve already done the heavy lifting. Here's how we can turn what you have into a strong first part of your pipeline, plus answer your question:

✅ Can You Use “Next-Day Price Prediction” as a Reference for That Day's Price?

If the column is labeled something like "Day-Ahead Price" or "Forecasted Price":

  • Yes, that’s often considered the settled market price for the upcoming day, based on auctions.

  • It's a standard reference for modeling energy prices in many studies, especially in Europe.

So yes — you can treat that as your target variable (i.e., the energy price for that specific date).

🧭 What You Can Do Now:

🔹 1. Organize Your Dataset

Create a clean DataFrame where each row = one day and includes:

  • date

  • solar_energy_production (MWh or MW)

  • wind_energy_production

  • irradiance

  • day_ahead_price (your target)

  • Optional: any derived features (moving averages, rolling std dev, etc.)

🔹 2. Visualize Your Data

Let’s check trends and correlations:

  • Plot time series for prices, production, and irradiance.

  • Plot scatter plots of production vs price to see relationships.

  • Compute correlations to identify strong predictors.

🔹 3. Feature Engineering

Add:

  • Lag features: yesterday's production or irradiance

  • Rolling means: past 7-day average wind/solar

  • Seasonal features: month, weekday, holiday flag

🔹 4. Train Baseline Model (Unimodal)

Use only this structured dataset:

  • XGBoost Regressor

  • Evaluate with RMSE or MAE

🔹 5. Set up for Multimodal

Prepare to add news sentiment later for fusion.

If you want, I can generate Python code to:

  • Clean and process your dataset

  • Add lag/rolling features

  • Visualize key trends

  • Train the first time-series regressor

    • Data: Daily WTI crude oil prices from 1986 to present.

    • Data: Daily spot prices by region, including U.S. benchmarks.

    • Access: EIA Natural Gas Weekly​EIA

    • Data: Daily Henry Hub natural gas spot prices from 1997 to present.

    • Access: FRED Henry Hub Prices​FRED+1FRED+1

    • Data: Daily and monthly natural gas prices, sourced from the EIA.

You said:
Concerning the data from DataHub on Natural Gas prices, it is not specified what unit the price in USD represents
ChatGPT said:

​The DataHub natural gas dataset you're using sources its data from the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA). While the DataHub page doesn't explicitly state the unit, the EIA typically reports natural gas prices in U.S. dollars per million British thermal units (USD/MMBtu). This is corroborated by other reputable sources, such as YCharts, which also report Henry Hub natural gas spot prices in USD per MMBtu .​YCharts

Therefore, it's reasonable to interpret the prices in the DataHub dataset as being in USD/MMBtu. This unit is standard for benchmarking natural gas prices, especially for Henry Hub spot prices.​

If you need assistance with integrating this data into your project or converting units for consistency, feel free to ask!

You said:
what was then the price of gas on 14 April 2025
ChatGPT said:

​On April 14, 2025, the Henry Hub natural gas spot price was $3.57 per million British thermal units (MMBtu). ​

This price point reflects the U.S. benchmark for natural gas and is commonly used in energy market analyses.​

If you need assistance integrating this data into your energy price prediction model or require further information on related energy metrics, feel free to ask!

You said:
Where can I find winf patterns in germany that relate to their wind energy production
ChatGPT said:

To correlate wind patterns in Germany with wind energy production, you’ll want historical wind speed data (ideally at hub height, e.g., 100m) from regions with wind farms. Here's where you can find it:

🌬️ Sources for Wind Data in Germany

1. Copernicus Climate Data Store (ERA5)

  • ✅ What it offers: Global hourly wind data at multiple altitudes (10m, 100m)

  • ✅ Resolution: ~30 km

  • ✅ Data Format: NetCDF

  • ✅ Access: https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/

  • 📌 Tip: Search for ERA5 hourly data on single levels, select "U component" and "V component" of wind.

2. Open Power System Data – Renewable Power Plants (DE)

  • ✅ What it offers: Locations and capacities of wind farms across Germany

  • ✅ Use case: Link wind speed data to actual plant locations

  • ✅ Access: https://data.open-power-system-data.org/renewable_power_plants/

3. Deutscher Wetterdienst (DWD – German Weather Service)

  • ✅ What it offers: Hourly/daily wind speed at various stations in Germany

  • ✅ Some datasets are free: via Climate Data Center

  • ✅ Access formats: CSV, ASCII

  • 📌 Note: Focus on "Windgeschwindigkeit" (wind speed) and possibly “Böen” (gusts)

4. Renewables.ninja

  • ✅ What it offers: Simulated wind power output from wind turbines based on historical weather data

  • ✅ Access: https://www.renewables.ninja/

  • ✅ Bonus: Can simulate for specific coordinates in Germany using turbine models (Vestas, Siemens, etc.)

  • 📌 Free with signup, allows data download via CSV or API

🛠️ How to Use the Data:

  • Combine wind speed at 100m with geolocated wind farm data to estimate potential output

  • Use ERA5 or DWD for raw wind data, and Renewables.ninja if you want a shortcut to estimated production

  • Add this as a feature to enhance your time series model’s inputs

Would you like help downloading wind data for a specific region in Germany or matching it with your existing wind production dataset?

​To obtain hourly electricity prices in Germany from 2015 to 2020, you have several reliable sources:​

📊 Open Power System Data (OPSD) – Time Series Package

  • Data: Provides hourly day-ahead electricity prices for Germany from 2015 to mid-2020.

  • Format: CSV files, with timestamps in both UTC and CET/CEST.

  • Access: OPSD Time Series Data Package

  • Note: This dataset is curated from ENTSO-E Transparency data and includes other variables like load, wind, and solar generation.​Ember Energy+1IIASA PURE+1data.open-power-system-data.org

🌐 ENTSO-E Transparency Platform

  • Data: Offers official hourly day-ahead electricity prices for Germany, including historical data.

  • Access: ENTSO-E Transparency Platform

  • Note: Data is available per bidding zone (e.g., DE-LU) and may require registration for bulk downloads.​Ember Energytransparency.entsoe.eudata.open-power-system-data.org+1m-transparency.entsoe.eu+1

📁 Ember – European Wholesale Electricity Price Data

  • Data: Provides cleaned and compiled hourly day-ahead electricity prices for European countries, including Germany.

  • Format: ZIP files containing CSVs per country.

  • Access: Ember Electricity Price Data

  • Note: Data is sourced from ENTSO-E and may include interpolated values for missing data.​IIASA PURE+2Ember Energy+2Ember Energy+2

If you need assistance with data processing or model development, feel free to ask!

You said:
Why are there negative prices in the ember dataset
ChatGPT said:

Great question — and a really important one when working with energy price data in places like Germany. Negative electricity prices aren’t a mistake — they’re actually a real and increasingly common phenomenon in modern energy markets.

⚡ Why Do Negative Electricity Prices Happen?

1. Oversupply of Renewable Energy

  • On very windy or sunny days, wind turbines and solar panels produce a lot of energy, especially in Germany where renewable penetration is high.

  • If supply exceeds demand, prices drop — sometimes even below zero.

2. Inflexibility of Traditional Power Plants

  • Coal, nuclear, and some gas plants can't ramp down quickly (or it’s more costly to stop and restart).

  • So, producers pay to keep generating rather than shut down temporarily — leading to negative prices.

3. Grid Constraints

  • Sometimes, electricity can’t be exported or stored fast enough due to grid limitations.

  • So, to maintain grid stability, market mechanisms incentivize reducing generation, again resulting in negative pricing.

4. Market Design

  • The day-ahead electricity market used in Europe and other regions is designed to clear supply and demand efficiently, even if it means prices go below zero.

  • This is a feature, not a bug — it helps ensure stability and signals where the system needs flexibility.

📌 What It Means for Your Model

  • Keep negative prices in your training data — they’re real and meaningful.

  • Consider engineering features that correlate with these events:

    • High wind/solar production

    • Low demand (e.g., weekends, holidays)

    • Seasonal patterns (spring and fall often see more negatives)

If you’d like, I can help you:

  • Flag and analyze negative price events

  • Visualize how they relate to renewables

  • Include this insight into your model training

Want to do a quick plot of negative prices over time?

You said:
I now have the following data between 2015 and 2020 for germany, energy prices per hour, energy consumption per hour, solar energy production per hour, wind energy production per hour, irradiance per hour, crude oil price per day, natural gas price per day. Would it be better to use all this data in one model to predict energy prices and then add the new section and combine everything using a multimodal approach, or would be better to make 4 models one for predicting renewable energy production, one for predicting consumer demand, one for predicting fuel prices and one for energy related news and then combine them all using a multi modal approach
ChatGPT said:

You’re sitting on a goldmine of rich, multi-dimensional data — and that gives you two solid paths. Here's a breakdown of both strategies and which might make more sense based on accuracy, explainability, and feasibility (especially with your Monday deadline).

⚙️ Option 1: Single-Model Approach (All structured data in one regressor)

✅ Pros:

  • Simple & fast to implement

  • Easier to align and clean data (one feature set, one target)

  • No need for complex fusion logic

  • You can quickly compare baseline vs. multimodal (just add text/sentiment later)

❌ Cons:

  • Less modular — hard to reuse sub-models

  • All signals are “flattened” — may lose interaction dynamics (e.g., fuel price → demand → price)

Best If:

  • You're short on time (🙋🏼‍♂️ now)

  • You want a strong, interpretable baseline model

  • You're starting from well-synced hourly/daily data

🧠 Option 2: Modular (Submodels + Fusion)

🧩 Submodels:

  • 🟩 Model 1: Predict wind/solar generation from irradiance & weather

  • 🟦 Model 2: Predict consumption/demand from time, season, prices

  • 🟨 Model 3: Predict fossil fuel price trends

  • 🟥 Model 4: Extract sentiment scores from news

  • 🎯 Final model: Predict energy price from submodel outputs

✅ Pros:

  • High modularity, extensibility

  • Easy to plug in updated sub-models (e.g., better fuel forecast)

  • Mimics real-world market behavior: energy price = f(renewables, demand, sentiment, fuel)

❌ Cons:

  • Requires more engineering (pipeline management, aligning outputs)

  • Risk of error propagation between models

  • You’ll need to define intermediate targets (e.g., predict future consumption?)

Best If:

  • You want explainable causal modeling

  • You have time to train/evaluate submodels

  • You want to simulate what-if scenarios (e.g., “what happens if gas price spikes?”)

💡 Recommendation (for this project timeline):

🥇 Hybrid Strategy:

Start with Option 1 (all structured data in one XGBoost model) to:

  • Get a solid working baseline

  • Visualize feature importance (fuel vs solar vs consumption)

  • Validate time alignment & feature effectiveness

Then, treat your news-based sentiment model as the second modality:

  • It’s natively separate (text), so easy to “fuse” later

  • You can compare baseline vs. multimodal performance

That lets you meet the multimodal requirement, without spreading too thin.

🛠️ Fusion Tip (Late Fusion):

  • Train a separate model that combines:

    • Predicted price from structured model

    • Sentiment score from news model

  • Could be a simple weighted average or meta-regressor

Would you like me to:

  • Help you build the baseline model input matrix (merge all hourly/daily data)?

  • Design the sentiment pipeline with VADER or TF-IDF?

  • Draft the fusion logic?

Pick your starting point and we’ll go step by step.

📁 Project Folder Structure (Git-Ready)

Here’s a suggested layout that supports clarity, reusability, and deployment:

java
energy-price-prediction/
│
├── data/                    ← Raw and preprocessed data
│   ├── raw/                 ← Original CSVs (as you have them now)
│   └── processed/           ← Cleaned, merged datasets
│
├── notebooks/               ← Jupyter notebooks for EDA, training, testing
│   ├── 01_data_merge.ipynb  ← Where you’ll merge and align your data
│   ├── 02_eda.ipynb         ← Visuals, correlations, etc.
│   └── 03_model_baseline.ipynb ← First model(s)
│
├── src/                     ← Python scripts (for later packaging)
│   ├── data_processing.py   ← Data cleaning + merging logic
│   ├── model.py             ← Training and evaluation logic
│   └── fusion.py            ← Late fusion logic (optional)
│
├── app/                     ← For the web API or Streamlit app (later)
│   └── main.py
│
├── Dockerfile               ← For deployment (required by project)
├── requirements.txt         ← List of pip dependencies
├── README.md                ← Project summary, how to run, etc.
└── .gitignore               ← Ignore checkpoints, pycache, etc.

🧠 Notebook vs. Scripts

  • ✅ Use Jupyter notebooks for:

    • Data merging

    • Visualization

    • EDA

    • Quick model experiments

  • 🧩 Later, convert reusable logic (like merging data or training) into .py scripts under src/. This will:

    • Clean up your GitHub repo

    • Make it easier to deploy or build a simple CLI/API

🔜 Immediate Next Step

You should now:

  1. Place all your original CSVs under data/raw/

  2. Create the notebook: notebooks/01_data_merge.ipynb

  3. Start merging the files:

    • Align hourly datasets on timestamp

    • Map daily prices (oil, gas) to each corresponding hour (forward fill or join)

    • Save the cleaned, merged dataset to data/processed/merged_energy_data.csv

🗂️ Data Overview & Issues

  • Has hourly energy prices with string datetime format (Datetime (UTC)).

    • Date conversion and cleaning

    • Merging with the hourly data (using merge_asof or forward-fill)

1. Standardize timestamps across all files (parse to pandas datetime).

2. Merge hourly datasets (energy_prices, irradiance, consumption/production).

You said:
I got this error on step 2: --------------------------------------------------------------------------- DateParseError Traceback (most recent call last) Cell In[2], line 13 11 df_production['utc_timestamp'] = pd.to_datetime(df_production['utc_timestamp']) 12 df_gas['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_gas['Date']) ---> 13 df_oil['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_oil['Date']) File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\tools\datetimes.py:1067, in to_datetime(arg, errors, dayfirst, yearfirst, utc, format, exact, unit, infer_datetime_format, origin, cache) 1065 result = arg.map(cache_array) 1066 else: -> 1067 values = convert_listlike(arg._values, format) 1068 result = arg._constructor(values, index=arg.index, name=arg.name) 1069 elif isinstance(arg, (ABCDataFrame, abc.MutableMapping)): File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\tools\datetimes.py:435, in _convert_listlike_datetimes(arg, format, name, utc, unit, errors, dayfirst, yearfirst, exact) 432 if format is not None and format != "mixed": 433 return _array_strptime_with_fallback(arg, name, utc, format, exact, errors) --> 435 result, tz_parsed = objects_to_datetime64( 436 arg, 437 dayfirst=dayfirst, 438 yearfirst=yearfirst, 439 utc=utc, 440 errors=errors, 441 allow_object=True, 442 ) ... File parsing.pyx:336, in pandas._libs.tslibs.parsing.parse_datetime_string() File parsing.pyx:666, in pandas._libs.tslibs.parsing.dateutil_parse() DateParseError: Unknown datetime string format, unable to parse: Date, at position 0 Output is truncated. View as a scrollable element or open in a text editor. Adjust cell output settings...
ChatGPT said:

That error is happening because the RBRTEd.csv (oil prices) file includes a header row that wasn't properly skipped, so pandas is trying to parse the string "Date" as an actual date, which it can't.

Let’s fix it! Here's what you need to do:

✅ Replace the line in your notebook:

Original (causing the error):

python
df_oil = pd.read_csv(files['oil'], skiprows=2, names=['Date', 'Oil_Price'])
df_oil['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_oil['Date'])

✅ New Version (with cleaning for extra headers):

python
# Load oil data and skip non-data rows
df_oil = pd.read_csv(files['oil'], skiprows=2, names=['Date', 'Oil_Price'])

# Remove rows where 'Date' can't be parsed (e.g., header text)
df_oil = df_oil[~df_oil['Date'].str.contains('Date|Sourcekey|Contents', na=False)]

# Now convert to datetime
df_oil['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_oil['Date'], errors='coerce')
df_oil = df_oil.dropna(subset=['Date'])

This code:

  • Skips the first two lines

  • Filters out any rows where "Date" is just part of a header string

  • Converts the remaining valid date strings

  • Drops rows where conversion failed

After this, you’ll be good to continue the merging steps!

Let me know if you'd like me to update the notebook file with this fix and reupload it.

Yes

This error is because the two columns you're merging on have slightly different datetime types:

  • df_production['utc_timestamp'] is timezone-aware (datetime64[ns, UTC])

  • df_prices['Datetime (UTC)'] is naive (datetime64[ns], no timezone info)

Convert both columns to the same timezone format before merging. Here's the fix to add before the merge step:

python
# Convert both timestamps to naive datetime (remove timezone info)
df_production['utc_timestamp'] = df_production['utc_timestamp'].dt.tz_localize(None)
df_prices['Datetime (UTC)'] = df_prices['Datetime (UTC)'].dt.tz_localize(None)

df_hourly = df_production.merge(df_prices, left_on='utc_timestamp', right_on='Datetime (UTC)', how='left')

df_oil['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_oil['Date'], errors='coerce')

ChatGPT said:

Ah — the gas price column didn’t rename properly because it looks like df_gas.rename(columns={'Price': 'Gas_Price'}) didn't persist when you merged it.

🔧 Here's the issue:

When you do this:

python
df_hourly = df_hourly.merge(df_gas.rename(columns={'Price': 'Gas_Price'}), ...)

You're renaming only during the merge, and not storing the renamed column anywhere else — so df_hourly still ends up with a 'Price' column (not 'Gas_Price').

✅ Clean Fix:

Instead of renaming inline, rename it before merging like this:

python
df_gas.rename(columns={'Price': 'Gas_Price'}, inplace=True)

Then:

python
df_hourly = df_hourly.merge(df_gas, left_on='date', right_on='Date', how='left')

And finally:

python
df_hourly['Gas_Price'].fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

You said:
The first 4 months in the oil prices are empty in the newly generated excel
ChatGPT said:

Thanks for spotting that! Empty values in the first few months of oil prices usually mean one of two things:

🔍 Likely Cause:

You’re merging the oil price after the gas price, and using forward fill (ffill) — but:

  • If the first dates in your hourly dataset are earlier than the first valid oil price, ffill doesn’t work (there’s nothing to fill from).

  • So the earliest values stay NaN.

✅ Quick Fix Options:

Option 1: Backward fill first, then forward fill

python
df_hourly['Oil_Price'].fillna(method='bfill', inplace=True)
df_hourly['Oil_Price'].fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

This will fill initial gaps from the next available value (e.g., 5th Jan fills 1st–4th Jan), then continue filling forward.

Option 2: Fill initial NaNs with first valid value manually

python
first_valid = df_hourly['Oil_Price'].dropna().iloc[0]
df_hourly['Oil_Price'].fillna(first_valid, inplace=True)

This is useful if you want to explicitly control what fills those early gaps (e.g., for modeling consistency).

Would you like me to patch the notebook with Option 1 (backfill + ffill) as a robust default?

You said:
But there are values in the original data
ChatGPT said:

Ah — got it. If the original df_oil data does contain values for those early dates, but they appear missing (NaN) after merging, then this is likely a date mismatch during the merge.

✅ Let’s verify what’s likely going wrong:

🔍 The df_hourly date is:

python
df_hourly['date'] = df_hourly['utc_timestamp'].dt.date  # dtype: object (just date, no time)

🔍 The df_oil['Date'] is:

python
df_oil['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_oil['Date'], errors='coerce')
df_oil['Date'] = df_oil['Date'].dt.date  # same type

But if oil price data starts after the first timestamp in df_hourly, even by one day, the first merge rows will miss values. For example:

  • If df_hourly starts at 2015-01-01

  • But df_oil starts at 2015-01-05

  • → No oil price data for Jan 1–4

✅ Next Step: Let’s Confirm the Earliest Dates

Add this quick check in your notebook to compare:

python
print("Earliest datetime in hourly data:", df_hourly['utc_timestamp'].min())
print("Earliest date in oil price data:", df_oil['Date'].min())

If df_oil['Date'].min() is after the hourly data's range — that’s the issue.

🛠️ Solution: Two options

  1. If data is missing in the CSV file itself: you'll need to manually fill it or fetch earlier entries.

  2. If it’s a merge issue (most likely): we’ll patch the merge logic or alignment to ensure all timestamps line up.

Want me to check this using the sample you uploaded, confirm the root cause, and patch the notebook accordingly?

You said:
The code returned: Earliest datetime in hourly data: 2014-12-31 23:00:00 Earliest date in oil price data: 1987-05-20
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — that confirms it: the oil price data does contain values going all the way back to 1987, so the issue is not missing values, it's likely a merge mismatch or column naming confusion.

🔍 Likely Cause

Your merge line:

python
df_hourly = df_hourly.merge(df_oil, on='Date', how='left')

…but the column 'Date' doesn't exist in df_hourly. You created a column called 'date' (lowercase). So the merge is being done on a key that doesn’t exist in both.

As a result, pandas does a cartesian product, not a match — and you get NaNs.

✅ Correct Merge Line:

Change this:

python
df_hourly = df_hourly.merge(df_oil, on='Date', how='left')

To this:

python
df_hourly = df_hourly.merge(df_oil, left_on='date', right_on='Date', how='left')

Then your Oil_Price values will match correctly!

🔄 Optional: Drop right_on='Date' after merging:

python
df_hourly.drop(columns='Date', inplace=True)

Would you like me to patch this fix into the notebook now?

python

python

This dynamically checks which of those two columns ('Date', 'date') are present and only drops the existing ones — no errors.

You said:
It's not working for the oil prices column, it put incorrect values. let's try something else. I'm going to remove all values before the window we are working in. Now give me a python code to put in the notebook so that I can fill in the missing values and change the date format to fit the rest of the data. Save the new file under another name
ChatGPT said:

Great call — trimming the dataset to your actual working window will simplify everything and ensure clean, aligned merges.

Let’s assume:

  • You’ve manually removed rows before 2015-01-01 in the df_oil dataset.

  • The column names remain: 'Date' and 'Oil_Price'.

✅ Here’s a Python cell to put in your notebook (after loading df_oil):

python
# Clean and standardize oil price data (after trimming to 2015–2020 manually)
df_oil['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_oil['Date'], errors='coerce')
df_oil = df_oil.dropna(subset=['Date'])

# Convert to just date (no time), to match the format in df_hourly
df_oil['Date'] = df_oil['Date'].dt.date

# Forward fill any missing oil prices
df_oil['Oil_Price'] = df_oil['Oil_Price'].replace('.', np.nan)
df_oil['Oil_Price'] = pd.to_numeric(df_oil['Oil_Price'], errors='coerce')
df_oil['Oil_Price'].fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

# Save cleaned oil data to a new file
df_oil.to_csv('../data/processed/cleaned_oil_prices.csv', index=False)
print("Saved cleaned oil price data to '../data/processed/cleaned_oil_prices.csv'")

💡 Notes:

  • It ensures the 'Date' column matches your hourly data’s df_hourly['date'] column format.

  • Handles stray "." values or string issues.

  • Saves a new file cleaned_oil_prices.csv under your processed folder.

Let me know when you're ready to move on to merging it back into df_hourly.

You said:

ChatGPT said:

You remembered right! To show the column headers and the first few rows of a DataFrame in your notebook, you can use:

python
df.head()

If you're checking a specific dataset like df_hourly, just do:

python
df_hourly.head()

You can also see more rows if needed, like:

python
df_hourly.head(10)

This will show the column names as well as the top n rows of data. Want a quick line to check all your merged data types too?

You said:
I wan to drop the columns: Datetime (UTC), Datetime (Local),Date_x and Date_y
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — here’s a clean line of code you can add in your notebook to drop those columns safely:

python
df_hourly.drop(columns=['Datetime (UTC)', 'Datetime (Local)', 'Date_x', 'Date_y'], inplace=True, errors='ignore')

🔍 Explanation:

  • inplace=True: updates the DataFrame without needing reassignment.

  • errors='ignore': skips columns that might not exist, avoiding a crash.

Let me know if you want to rename or reorder the remaining columns too!

You said:
Looks like there are missing data before and after certain dates. What can I do to remove these rows
ChatGPT said:

To remove rows with missing data before or after certain dates, you have a couple of solid strategies depending on what you want:

✅ Option 1: Drop all rows with any missing values

This is the simplest:

python
df_hourly.dropna(inplace=True)

But this can be harsh — if you're missing just one value in a row, the whole thing goes.

✅ Option 2: Filter to a date range where data is complete

If you know your clean date range (say from 2016-01-01 to 2019-12-31), do this:

python
df_hourly = df_hourly[(df_hourly['utc_timestamp'] >= '2016-01-01') & (df_hourly['utc_timestamp'] <= '2019-12-31')]

Optional: Then drop any remaining NaNs if needed:

python
df_hourly.dropna(inplace=True)

✅ Option 3: Drop rows missing only specific critical columns

If you only care about certain fields like prices or consumption:

python
df_hourly.dropna(subset=['Gas_Price', 'Oil_Price', 'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency'], inplace=True)

Would you like help visualizing where those gaps are (missing data heatmap or timeline plot) before trimming?

You said:
Is there a code to check if there are missing data between 2 specific dates?
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely! If you want to check for missing data between two specific dates, you can filter your DataFrame and then inspect it. Here's a step-by-step code snippet:

✅ Example Code

python
# Define your date range
start_date = '2016-01-01'
end_date = '2016-12-31'

# Filter the DataFrame for that range
df_range = df_hourly[(df_hourly['utc_timestamp'] >= start_date) & (df_hourly['utc_timestamp'] <= end_date)]

# Check for any missing values
missing_summary = df_range.isnull().sum()

# Show only columns with missing data
print(missing_summary[missing_summary > 0])

💡 Optional: See rows with missing data

If you want to see the actual rows:

python
df_range[df_range.isnull().any(axis=1)]

This will show you every row between your dates that has at least one NaN.

Want to visualize missing data over time next (like a heatmap or time gaps)?

python
df_hourly = df_hourly[df_hourly['utc_timestamp'] <= '2019-12-30']

✅ This will keep all rows up to and including 2019-12-30 and drop everything after.

python

You said:
I have missing data in DE_wind_generation_actual 74 DE_wind_profile 74, how do i fill the missing data
ChatGPT said:

Great — since you have only 74 missing values in each, and they're related (wind_generation and wind_profile), you can handle them a few ways depending on how you'd like to treat the gaps:

✅ Option 1: Forward Fill (propagate last known value)

This is common for time series:

python
df_hourly['DE_wind_generation_actual'].fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)
df_hourly['DE_wind_profile'].fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

✅ Option 2: Backward Fill

If you prefer to use the next value instead of the previous:

python
df_hourly['DE_wind_generation_actual'].fillna(method='bfill', inplace=True)
df_hourly['DE_wind_profile'].fillna(method='bfill', inplace=True)

✅ Option 3: Interpolate

If the gaps are short and values are numeric, this is great for smooth transitions:

python
df_hourly['DE_wind_generation_actual'].interpolate(method='linear', inplace=True)
df_hourly['DE_wind_profile'].interpolate(method='linear', inplace=True)

👉 I recommend using .interpolate() if the missing rows are spread across the timeline and not at the very beginning or end.

what is an .md file

An .md file is a Markdown file — a lightweight plain text format used to write formatted documents without needing complex software.

📘 What Makes Markdown Special:

You can use simple symbols (like #, *, and []()) to create:

SymbolResultExample
#Headings# Title, ## Subtitle
* or -Bullet points* Item 1
**text**Bold text**important**
*text*Italics*emphasis*
```Code blockspython print("hi")
[link](url)Hyperlinks[Google](https://google.com)

📁 Where It’s Used:

  • README.md in GitHub projects 📄

  • Documentation pages for software 📘

  • Static site generators (like Jekyll or Hugo) 🌐

🛠️ How to Open It:

  • Any text editor (VSCode, Notepad, Sublime)

  • Markdown editors like Typora or Obsidian

  • GitHub auto-renders .md beautifully

You said:
what do you mean by feature comparisons

​

You said:
You responded with blank
ChatGPT said:

Oops — that was unintentional 😅 Here’s what I meant by feature comparisons:

🔍 Feature Comparisons in EDA

These are analyses where you compare one feature (variable) to another to find patterns, trends, or relationships.

Here are a few examples:

📈 1. Feature vs Target

Compare independent variables to your target:
💡 "How does this feature affect price?"

python
sns.scatterplot(data=df, x='DE_solar_generation_actual', y='Price (EUR/MWhe)')

Or line plots over time:

python
df[['Price (EUR/MWhe)', 'DE_wind_generation_actual']].plot(figsize=(15, 5))

📊 2. Feature Distribution Comparisons

Compare how features behave across different time slices, categories, or events:

python
sns.histplot(df['DE_wind_generation_actual'], bins=50)

Or compare multiple features’ distributions:

python
df[['DE_wind_generation_actual', 'DE_solar_generation_actual']].plot(kind='density')

🔄 3. Rolling or Lag-Based Comparisons

Check short-term vs long-term behavior (good for time series):

python
df['Price_rolling_mean'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(window=24).mean()
df[['Price (EUR/MWhe)', 'Price_rolling_mean']].plot(figsize=(15, 5))

Would you like me to add some of these comparisons into the EDA notebook? If yes, do you want:

  • Scatter plots (price vs solar/wind/gas)?

  • Rolling window trends?

  • Seasonal breakdowns (like average price by month)?

You said:
No just give me the python code I can add it manually. I want scatter plots of price vs solar/wind/gas/oil/load/temperature and rolling window trends both short and long term
ChatGPT said:

Perfect! Here’s the Python code you can paste directly into your notebook for:

📌 1. Scatter Plots: Price vs Key Features

python
features = [
    'DE_solar_generation_actual',
    'DE_wind_generation_actual',
    'Gas_Price',
    'Oil_Price',
    'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency',
    'temperature'
]

for feature in features:
    plt.figure(figsize=(8, 5))
    sns.scatterplot(data=df, x=feature, y='Price (EUR/MWhe)', alpha=0.5)
    plt.title(f'Price vs {feature}')
    plt.xlabel(feature)
    plt.ylabel('Price (EUR/MWhe)')
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

📌 2. Rolling Window Trends

➤ Add short-term (24h) & long-term (168h ~ weekly) rolling averages:

python
df['price_roll_24h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(window=24).mean()
df['price_roll_168h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(window=168).mean()

➤ Plot the original vs rolling trends:

python
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].plot(label='Original', alpha=0.4)
df['price_roll_24h'].plot(label='24h Rolling Avg')
df['price_roll_168h'].plot(label='168h Rolling Avg (Weekly)')
plt.title('Energy Price with Short and Long-Term Rolling Averages')
plt.ylabel('EUR/MWhe')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

Let me know if you also want seasonal plots (like price by month or weekday)!

You said:
I need a code to identify significant peaks and dips in the price trend
ChatGPT said:

Great idea! Identifying significant peaks and dips (local maxima and minima) in the price trend is a powerful part of EDA — especially in volatile markets like energy.

✅ Here’s a code snippet to detect and visualize peaks and dips using scipy.signal.find_peaks:

python
from scipy.signal import find_peaks

# Extract the price series
price_series = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# Find peaks (high points)
peaks, _ = find_peaks(price_series, distance=24)  # `distance=24` avoids noise from hourly fluctuation

# Find dips (inverted peaks)
dips, _ = find_peaks(-price_series, distance=24)

# Plotting
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(price_series, label='Price', alpha=0.7)
plt.plot(price_series.iloc[peaks], 'go', label='Peaks')
plt.plot(price_series.iloc[dips], 'ro', label='Dips')
plt.title('Significant Peaks and Dips in Energy Price')
plt.xlabel('Time')
plt.ylabel('Price (EUR/MWhe)')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

💡 Customization:

  • You can adjust distance=24 to spread out or capture more/less frequent changes.

  • For higher thresholds:

python
find_peaks(price_series, height=100)  # Only peaks above 100

Want me to show how to extract the dates and values of the top 10 biggest price spikes or crashes too?

You said:
yes please adjust the code to include that too
ChatGPT said:

Awesome — here’s the updated code to:

✅ Detect peaks and dips
✅ Plot them
✅ And extract the top 10 highest peaks and lowest dips with their timestamps

🔍 Complete Python Code for Peak & Dip Detection + Analysis

python
from scipy.signal import find_peaks

# Extract price series
price_series = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# Find peaks and dips
peaks, _ = find_peaks(price_series, distance=24)
dips, _ = find_peaks(-price_series, distance=24)

# Plotting
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(price_series, label='Price', alpha=0.7)
plt.plot(price_series.iloc[peaks], 'go', label='Peaks')
plt.plot(price_series.iloc[dips], 'ro', label='Dips')
plt.title('Significant Peaks and Dips in Energy Price')
plt.xlabel('Time')
plt.ylabel('Price (EUR/MWhe)')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# Extract peak and dip values with timestamps
peaks_df = price_series.iloc[peaks].sort_values(ascending=False).head(10)
dips_df = price_series.iloc[dips].sort_values(ascending=True).head(10)

# Display top 10 peaks
print("🔼 Top 10 Highest Price Peaks:")
display(peaks_df.to_frame(name='Price (EUR/MWhe)'))

# Display top 10 dips
print("🔽 Top 10 Lowest Price Dips:")
display(dips_df.to_frame(name='Price (EUR/MWhe)'))

Let me know if you’d like to annotate these points directly on the plot or match them with other features (like solar/wind/fuel data during peaks)!

You said:
I think it would be more logical to find these peaks and dips on a moving average say weekly, can you adjust the code to do that
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely — that’s a smart move. Using a weekly rolling average (168 hours) smooths out noise and highlights more meaningful trends for peak/dip detection.

✅ Here’s the adjusted code using a 168-hour rolling average (1 week):

python
from scipy.signal import find_peaks

# Step 1: Compute 168-hour (weekly) rolling average of the price
df['price_roll_168h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(window=168).mean()

# Step 2: Drop NaNs from the rolling column (beginning of the series)
smoothed_price = df['price_roll_168h'].dropna()

# Step 3: Find peaks and dips on the smoothed series
peaks, _ = find_peaks(smoothed_price, distance=24)
dips, _ = find_peaks(-smoothed_price, distance=24)

# Step 4: Plot smoothed price with peaks/dips
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(smoothed_price, label='168h Rolling Avg', alpha=0.8)
plt.plot(smoothed_price.iloc[peaks], 'go', label='Peaks')
plt.plot(smoothed_price.iloc[dips], 'ro', label='Dips')
plt.title('Significant Weekly Rolling Peaks and Dips in Energy Price')
plt.xlabel('Time')
plt.ylabel('EUR/MWhe (Weekly Avg)')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# Step 5: Extract top 10 peaks and dips from rolling avg
peaks_df = smoothed_price.iloc[peaks].sort_values(ascending=False).head(10)
dips_df = smoothed_price.iloc[dips].sort_values(ascending=True).head(10)

print("🔼 Top 10 Weekly Price Peaks (Rolling Average):")
display(peaks_df.to_frame(name='Price (EUR/MWhe)'))

print("🔽 Top 10 Weekly Price Dips (Rolling Average):")
display(dips_df.to_frame(name='Price (EUR/MWhe)'))

Let me know if you want to align these peak timestamps with:

  • energy demand 🧍‍♂️⚡

  • solar/wind availability 🌞💨

  • or even fuel prices 📉📈

We can build context around the events!

You said:
Yes please allign them with those
ChatGPT said:

Awesome — this will give you real insight into the driving forces behind those peak and dip events.

Here’s how to align the top 10 peaks and dips in the weekly rolling average with:

✅ Solar
✅ Wind
✅ Load (consumption)
✅ Gas price
✅ Oil price

✅ Full Code to Align Weekly Peaks & Dips with Other Variables

python
# Required columns to extract for alignment
context_cols = [
    'DE_solar_generation_actual',
    'DE_wind_generation_actual',
    'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency',
    'Gas_Price',
    'Oil_Price'
]

# Extract top 10 peaks and dips in rolling average
top_peaks = smoothed_price.iloc[peaks].sort_values(ascending=False).head(10)
top_dips = smoothed_price.iloc[dips].sort_values(ascending=True).head(10)

# Align peaks and dips with context features
peaks_context = df.loc[top_peaks.index, context_cols]
dips_context = df.loc[top_dips.index, context_cols]

# Combine with price values
peaks_context.insert(0, 'Price (EUR/MWhe)', top_peaks)
dips_context.insert(0, 'Price (EUR/MWhe)', top_dips)

# Display
print("🔼 Top 10 Peaks - Aligned Context")
display(peaks_context)

print("🔽 Top 10 Dips - Aligned Context")
display(dips_context)

🧠 What You Can Do Next:

  • Compute correlation patterns during peak vs dip periods

  • Export these for your report or dashboard

  • Visualize contextual differences (e.g., bar chart comparing avg solar/wind during peaks vs dips)

Want a bar chart or radar plot to compare the conditions around peaks vs dips visually?

You said:
what is the "distance" in find_peaks
ChatGPT said:

Great question!

🔍 distance in scipy.signal.find_peaks

The distance parameter sets the minimum number of samples (data points) between two consecutive peaks.

💡 Why it's important:

  • It prevents detecting too many small, noisy peaks that are close together.

  • It's especially useful for time series data where you expect peaks to occur at a certain temporal spacing.

🕐 In Time Series:

Let’s say your data is hourly:

python
distance=24  # means: at least 24 hours (1 day) between two detected peaks
distance=168  # means: at least 1 week between peaks

🔧 Example:

python
peaks, _ = find_peaks(price_series, distance=24)

This tells the function:

"Only return peaks that are at least 24 data points apart (1 day if hourly data)."

🧠 Tip:

You can tune distance based on the granularity you want:

  • Short-term volatility → smaller distance

  • Major events/trends → larger distance

Let me know your use case and I can help you pick the best value!

You said:
Okay let's move on to the next step
ChatGPT said:

Nice! You're making solid progress — let’s jump into the next major step after EDA, which is typically:

🧠 3. Baseline Modeling: Predicting Energy Prices

We'll start by building a structured-data-only model (before adding multimodal stuff like news/text).

🧰 Key Tasks Ahead:

  1. Feature Selection & Engineering

    • Use lag values? Rolling averages? Ratios (e.g., solar/load)?

    • Drop irrelevant columns (e.g., timestamp)

  2. Train-Test Split

    • Use time-based split (e.g., train on 2015–2018, test on 2019)

  3. Modeling

    • Start with a simple and strong model like XGBoost or LightGBM

  4. Evaluation

    • Use metrics like MAE, RMSE

    • Plot predictions vs actual prices

Would you like me to:

  • Create a new notebook (03_baseline_model.ipynb)?

  • Or just give you the code to start training?

Also: do you have a target column confirmed? Is it "Price (EUR/MWhe)"?

You said:
Yes please create the notebook. The target column is "Price (EUR/MWhe)". But first should we normalize the values since they are different in terms of scale? also can you eplain a bit in detail how XGBoost and Light GBM work and why they fit this prediction time series setup?
ChatGPT said:

Perfect! Before I generate the modeling notebook, let’s go through your questions — smart ones, by the way.

🔄 Should You Normalize the Values?

✅ For XGBoost/LightGBM:

  • NO, you don’t need to normalize or scale your features.

  • These models are tree-based, and tree splits don’t rely on distance or magnitude — only on relative comparisons (e.g., "is feature > 7?").

Unlike linear models or neural networks, tree-based models are scale-invariant.

👉 So you’re safe leaving your features as-is. But you may still want to:

  • Create ratios (e.g., solar / load)

  • Log-transform features with heavy skew

  • Standardize only if you're comparing with a model that needs it (like ridge regression or neural nets)

🌳 How XGBoost & LightGBM Work (and Why They're Great for You)

✅ Both are gradient boosting machines (GBMs)

They build a series of decision trees, where each new tree:

  • Tries to fix the errors made by the previous one

  • Learns patterns in the residuals (the leftover error)

⚙️ High-Level Mechanics:

FeatureXGBoostLightGBM
Tree Growth StrategyLevel-wise (deeper but slower)Leaf-wise (faster, deeper where needed)
SpeedFastEven faster (optimized for large datasets)
RegularizationBuilt-in (L1/L2)Also supported
Missing Value HandlingAutomaticAutomatic
Feature ImportanceYesYes

🚀 Why They’re Great for Time Series Regression:

✅ Can handle non-linear, multi-feature relationships
✅ Work well with lags, rolling stats, seasonal trends
✅ Handle missing values without preprocessing
✅ Produce interpretable feature importance
✅ Work with small to medium datasets without heavy tuning

⚠️ One Note for Time Series:

Don’t use random train-test splits — use a time-based split to avoid leakage from the future.

✅ Next Step: I’ll now generate a 03_baseline_model.ipynb notebook

It will:

  • Select useful features

  • Split data by time

  • Train XGBoost

  • Plot predictions

  • Evaluate RMSE / MAE

Let’s do it 🚀

✅ Your modeling notebook is ready: 📘 03_baseline_model.ipynb

It walks you through:

  • Feature selection

  • Time-based split

  • Training an XGBoost regressor

  • Evaluating with MAE & RMSE

  • Plotting predictions vs actual

Let me know when you're ready to:

  • Tune hyperparameters

  • Try LightGBM

  • Or start combining structured + news data in a multimodal setup! ​​

You said:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------- TypeError Traceback (most recent call last) Cell In[8], line 3 1 # Compute error metrics 2 mae = mean_absolute_error(y_test, y_pred) ----> 3 rmse = mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred, squared=False) 5 print(f'MAE: {mae:.2f}') 6 print(f'RMSE: {rmse:.2f}') File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\_param_validation.py:194, in validate_params.<locals>.decorator.<locals>.wrapper(*args, **kwargs) 191 func_sig = signature(func) 193 # Map *args/**kwargs to the function signature --> 194 params = func_sig.bind(*args, **kwargs) 195 params.apply_defaults() 197 # ignore self/cls and positional/keyword markers File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\inspect.py:3277, in Signature.bind(self, *args, **kwargs) 3272 def bind(self, /, *args, **kwargs): 3273 """Get a BoundArguments object, that maps the passed args 3274 and kwargs to the function's signature. Raises TypeError 3275 if the passed arguments can not be bound. 3276 """ -> 3277 return self._bind(args, kwargs) File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\inspect.py:3266, in Signature._bind(self, args, kwargs, partial) ... 3267 'got an unexpected keyword argument {arg!r}'.format( 3268 arg=next(iter(kwargs)))) 3270 return self._bound_arguments_cls(self, arguments) TypeError: got an unexpected keyword argument 'squared' Output is truncated. View as a scrollable element or open in a text editor. Adjust cell output settings...
ChatGPT said:

Ah — looks like you're using a version of scikit-learn that doesn’t support the squared parameter in mean_squared_error.

That option was introduced in scikit-learn 0.22 — older versions don’t recognize it.

✅ Quick Fix: Compute RMSE manually

Replace this line:

python
rmse = mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred, squared=False)

With:

python
rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred))

This does the same thing — takes the square root of the MSE manually.

Let me know if you’d like to add feature importance plots or switch to LightGBM next!

You said:
The prediction was able to follow the trend but it had the following errors: MAE: 8.28 RMSE: 10.78, which is large given the scale of prices (typically 0-100 euros). How can I tweek these features
ChatGPT said:

You're off to a solid start — your model captures the trend, which is huge 🎯
Now let's talk feature tweaks to reduce that error and improve prediction accuracy.

🔍 First: Understand Your Current Error

  • MAE ~ 8.3 means you're off by ~8 EUR per hour on average

  • RMSE ~ 10.8 means larger errors are penalized — you have some big mistakes

Given that your prices mostly range from 0 to 100 EUR, that’s decent, but let’s sharpen it.

🔧 6 Ways to Improve Your Features

1. Add Lag Features (Temporal Memory)

You're doing time series — so let’s give the model a memory of the past:

python
df['price_lag_1h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(1)
df['price_lag_24h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24)
df['price_lag_168h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(168)  # weekly

You can also add lags for consumption or renewables:

python
df['solar_lag_24h'] = df['DE_solar_generation_actual'].shift(24)

2. Rolling Averages (Trend Smoothing)

These help with trend awareness, just like we used in EDA:

python
df['price_roll_24h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(24).mean()
df['price_roll_168h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(168).mean()

Also useful for features like wind, load, or temperature.

3. Calendar Features (Seasonality Awareness)

Energy prices are often cyclical (hour of day, weekday, season):

python
df['hour'] = df.index.hour
df['dayofweek'] = df.index.dayofweek
df['month'] = df.index.month

Trees love categorical-like features like hour or dayofweek.

4. Ratios & Interactions (Efficiency Indicators)

Create smart relationships like:

python
df['solar_load_ratio'] = df['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
df['wind_load_ratio'] = df['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']

This gives insight into renewables' share of the grid, which often affects prices.

5. Remove Redundant/Noisy Features

Check correlation or feature importance and drop things that:

  • Are highly correlated with each other

  • Don’t contribute meaningfully (can test with permutation importance)

6. Hyperparameter Tuning

Once you boost your features, revisit:

  • n_estimators, learning_rate, max_depth

  • Use GridSearchCV or optuna if time allows

📈 Want a ready-to-go feature engineering block you can paste into the notebook?

Or would you like me to regenerate the notebook with all these additions and retrain?

You said:
no need just give me the block and where to paste it
ChatGPT said:

Awesome! Here's your feature engineering block — fully loaded and ready to go 🚀

🔧 📦 Feature Engineering Block

🔁 Paste this after data loading and before train-test split:

Replace your existing # Feature Engineering cell with this:

python
# --- Feature Engineering ---

# Base features
features = [
    'DE_solar_generation_actual',
    'DE_wind_generation_actual',
    'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency',
    'Gas_Price',
    'Oil_Price',
    'irradiance',
    'temperature'
]

# Lag features
df['price_lag_1h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(1)
df['price_lag_24h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24)
df['price_lag_168h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(168)

# Rolling averages
df['price_roll_24h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(24).mean()
df['price_roll_168h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(168).mean()

# Calendar features
df['hour'] = df.index.hour
df['dayofweek'] = df.index.dayofweek
df['month'] = df.index.month

# Ratio features
df['solar_load_ratio'] = df['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
df['wind_load_ratio'] = df['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']

# Final feature list
features += [
    'price_lag_1h', 'price_lag_24h', 'price_lag_168h',
    'price_roll_24h', 'price_roll_168h',
    'hour', 'dayofweek', 'month',
    'solar_load_ratio', 'wind_load_ratio'
]

# Drop rows with missing values (due to shifting/rolling)
df_model = df[features + ['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].dropna()

🧠 Then continue with:

python
# Train-test split
train = df_model[df_model.index < '2019-01-01']
test = df_model[df_model.index >= '2019-01-01']
...

Those results are 🔥:

  • RMSE: 3.13 → Big errors are mostly gone — smooth predictions

📊 What This Means:

You're now nailing the price prediction with minimal error over time — and you're doing it with purely structured data.

💡 Why This Worked:

  • Lag features gave your model temporal memory

  • Rolling averages helped it smooth noise

  • Calendar features let it learn seasonality

  • Ratios gave insight into demand-supply dynamics

Want me to give you a snippet for feature importance or prep for multimodal fusion?

You said:
But first I need to understand something. What I'm trying to do is predict into the future. So lets say today is Saturday and I want to know the prices for tomorrow sunday up to next saturday. I will not have the irradiance, solar production, wind production, oil prices, gas prices temperatures and so on for the upcoming week since this is all recorded data and we're talking about the future. Does the model we made take that into consideration or is more of a real time model that has to have the data of the features in order to predict the result
ChatGPT said:

That’s a super important question, and I’m really glad you’re thinking about it now — because you're about to transition from historical modeling to true forecasting.

❓ So does your current model “predict into the future”?

🔴 Not yet — your current model is a "nowcasting" model, meaning:

It predicts the price at a given hour using features from the same hour (e.g., solar, wind, gas price at that time).

✅ This works great if you have access to all the features at prediction time (like in real-time systems).

🚧 But for actual forecasting, the challenge is this:

You want to predict prices for hours/days into the future, when most input features (e.g. solar, wind, temperature, fuel prices) are not yet known.

So: ❌ You can’t use solar_generation or gas_price for next Wednesday if it hasn’t happened yet.

✅ You Have 3 Main Options Now:

1. Forecast those inputs too (multi-step modeling)

Build separate models to predict each feature into the future, like:

  • solar_gen_t+1, wind_gen_t+1, etc. Then feed those predicted features into your price model.

✔️ More accurate
❌ Complex (chains models)

2. Use only past & known features

Train a new version of the model that uses only:

  • Lags: price_lag_24h, wind_lag_24h, etc.

  • Calendar features: hour, weekday, month

  • Forecasted weather (if available)

This model predicts price based on what you know up to today, not from the same time window.

✔️ Ready for production
❌ Slightly less powerful than option 1

3. Use external forecast data

Some sources give:

  • Weather forecasts (irradiance, temperature, wind speed)

  • Fuel price forecasts You can plug those into the model as future inputs.

🧠 Recommendation for Your Project:

✅ Retrain a version of your model using only:

  • Lag features (from past known data)

  • Calendar features

  • Rolling stats (that only use the past)

Then you'll have a model that truly forecasts using known signals.

Want me to generate that updated version of the model for you? (Only past features, ready for weekly forecasting)?

You said:
What you are suggesting is option 2 correct? if so yes please create a new notebook to test that
ChatGPT said:

✅ Your new forecasting notebook is ready:
📘 04_forecasting_model.ipynb

It trains a model using only past and known features (lags, calendar, rolling) — making it suitable for real-world future price prediction when upcoming data isn't available.

Let me know how the results turn out — or if you want to compare this with a LightGBM version next! ​​

You said:
file not found
ChatGPT said:

✅ Your notebook is now available: 📘 04_forecasting_model.ipynb

This version is designed for true forecasting — using only past-known features like lagged prices and calendar data. Perfect for predicting the future without needing future sensor inputs.

Run it and let me know how the results compare! ​​

You said:
Results: MAE: 2.00 RMSE: 3.36... But let me first make sure I understand how this model works. So this model discards All the data except the price of energy, then generates features that are 1 hour, 1 day and 1 week behind to predict the next hour. And when testing, does this lagged feature take the predicted value or the actual value from the test set
ChatGPT said:

You're spot on — and your understanding is almost perfect! Let's break it down and clear up the one key nuance:

✅ How This Forecasting Model Works:

🧠 What it uses:

  • Only the past values of the target variable (Price (EUR/MWhe))

  • Time-based features like hour, dayofweek, and month

  • No future or same-hour input data (like solar, wind, gas, etc.)

🔁 Feature Creation:

The model builds features like:

  • price_lag_1h: price at t−1 hour

  • price_lag_24h: price at t−24 hours

  • price_lag_168h: price at t−168 hours (1 week ago)

  • Plus rolling means over those windows

All of this is generated using historical actual values during training.

🧪 During Testing (Very Important):

👉 Does it use the actual values or predicted values for lags?
➡️ In this notebook setup: it uses the actual historical values from the test set to create lag features — because they’re already available in the dataset.

❗ Implication:

This means it simulates forecasting only 1 step ahead at a time, assuming you know the past actual values up to the current point.

In other words, it does not roll forward and does not use its own predictions as inputs for the next step.

🔮 For True Multi-Step Forecasting (e.g., 1 week ahead):

You’d need to:

  1. Use the model to predict t+1

  2. Feed that prediction into lag features to get t+2

  3. Repeat (auto-regressively)

This is called recursive forecasting, and it's how you'd simulate a real forecast horizon (e.g., predicting Sunday to Saturday in one go).

Would you like to see how to build that loop (recursive forecasting for 7 days)? Or do you want to stick to 1-hour-ahead predictions for now?

You said:
No lets see it for 7 day recursive forecasting
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — let’s do true 7-day (168-hour) recursive forecasting, step by step!

🔁 What We'll Do (Concept)

We’ll:

  1. Start from the last known row in your dataset (e.g., Saturday 23:00)

  2. Predict the price for Sunday 00:00 using lag features

  3. Add that prediction to our data

  4. Recompute the lag features and predict Sunday 01:00

  5. Repeat until we get all 168 future hours

✅ Code to Add at the End of Your Forecasting Notebook:

python
from datetime import timedelta

# Copy the latest known data (last row of full df_model) as our starting point
last_known = df_model.copy().iloc[-1:].copy()

# Prepare an empty DataFrame to hold future predictions
future_predictions = []

# Set the number of hours to forecast (7 days = 168 hours)
forecast_horizon = 168

for step in range(1, forecast_horizon + 1):
    next_timestamp = last_known.index[-1] + timedelta(hours=1)

    # Create next row
    new_row = {
        'price_lag_1h': last_known[target].iloc[-1],  # last predicted or real price
        'price_lag_24h': last_known[target].shift(23).iloc[-1] if len(last_known) >= 24 else np.nan,
        'price_lag_168h': last_known[target].shift(167).iloc[-1] if len(last_known) >= 168 else np.nan,
        'price_roll_24h': last_known[target].rolling(24).mean().iloc[-1] if len(last_known) >= 24 else np.nan,
        'price_roll_168h': last_known[target].rolling(168).mean().iloc[-1] if len(last_known) >= 168 else np.nan,
        'hour': next_timestamp.hour,
        'dayofweek': next_timestamp.dayofweek,
        'month': next_timestamp.month
    }

    new_row_df = pd.DataFrame([new_row], index=[next_timestamp])
    
    # Drop if any NaNs exist (optional)
    if new_row_df.isnull().any(axis=1).iloc[0]:
        print(f"Insufficient history at step {step}, skipping forecast.")
        break

    # Predict next price
    prediction = model.predict(new_row_df[features])[0]

    # Add prediction to the new_row_df
    new_row_df[target] = prediction

    # Append to results
    future_predictions.append(new_row_df)

    # Add to last_known so it can be used in future steps
    last_known = pd.concat([last_known, new_row_df])

# Combine all predicted rows
future_df = pd.concat(future_predictions)

# Plot
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(future_df.index, future_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'], label='Forecasted Price', color='orange')
plt.title('7-Day Recursive Forecast of Energy Price')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('EUR/MWhe')
plt.grid(True)
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

🧠 Notes:

  • It starts from the most recent available data

  • Uses your model + previous predictions to move forward

  • Skips prediction if there isn’t enough lag history (first 24/168 steps)

Want me to integrate this logic into the forecasting notebook for you directly?

ChatGPT said:

That error means the loop never successfully made a prediction, so future_predictions stayed empty → nothing to concatenate.

This happened because the model requires at least 168 hours of historical data for lag and rolling features, but last_known started with only one row, so it couldn't compute price_lag_168h, price_roll_168h, etc.

✅ Here's the fix:

Start last_known from a longer recent slice — e.g., the last 200 rows — to give it the memory it needs:

🔧 Replace this line:

python
last_known = df_model.copy().iloc[-1:].copy()

🔁 With this:

python
last_known = df_model.copy().iloc[-200:].copy()

That gives enough data to calculate:

  • lag_168h (168 rows back)

  • roll_168h (168-hour window)

Try that and rerun — you should start seeing predictions and a forecast plot. Want me to repackage all this logic into an updated version of your forecasting notebook too?

ChatGPT said:

Nice! Since your recursive forecast is working now, let’s compare the predicted values to the actual prices from the same time period.

✅ Step-by-step: Compare Forecast vs Actual

Assuming your future_df contains 168 forecasted hours and has Price (EUR/MWhe) as the prediction…

🧠 Add this block after your forecast plot:

python
# Extract the matching true values from the dataset
actual_prices = df.loc[future_df.index, 'Price (EUR/MWhe)'].dropna()

# Align the predicted and actual values
comparison_df = future_df[['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].rename(columns={'Price (EUR/MWhe)': 'Predicted'})
comparison_df['Actual'] = actual_prices

# Drop any timestamps where actual value is missing (just in case)
comparison_df.dropna(inplace=True)

# Plot comparison
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(comparison_df.index, comparison_df['Predicted'], label='Predicted', color='orange')
plt.plot(comparison_df.index, comparison_df['Actual'], label='Actual', color='blue')
plt.title('7-Day Forecast: Predicted vs Actual Energy Prices')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('EUR/MWhe')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# Calculate evaluation metrics
mae = mean_absolute_error(comparison_df['Actual'], comparison_df['Predicted'])
rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(comparison_df['Actual'], comparison_df['Predicted']))

print(f"Forecast MAE: {mae:.2f}")
print(f"Forecast RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

Let me know how the forecast stacks up — or if you want to try a LightGBM version or smooth out predictions for better accuracy.

python
# Load full price data to get actual future values
df_prices = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/Germany.csv', parse_dates=['Datetime (UTC)'])
df_prices.set_index('Datetime (UTC)', inplace=True)
df_prices = df_prices.sort_index()

# Extract actual prices for the forecasted range
actual_prices = df_prices.loc[future_df.index, 'Price (EUR/MWhe)'].dropna()

# Combine with predictions
comparison_df = future_df[['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].rename(columns={'Price (EUR/MWhe)': 'Predicted'})
comparison_df['Actual'] = actual_prices

# Drop rows without matching actual data
comparison_df.dropna(inplace=True)

# Plot comparison
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(comparison_df.index, comparison_df['Predicted'], label='Predicted', color='orange')
plt.plot(comparison_df.index, comparison_df['Actual'], label='Actual', color='blue')
plt.title('7-Day Recursive Forecast: Predicted vs Actual Prices')
plt.xlabel('Timestamp')
plt.ylabel('EUR/MWhe')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# Evaluation
mae = mean_absolute_error(comparison_df['Actual'], comparison_df['Predicted'])
rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(comparison_df['Actual'], comparison_df['Predicted']))

print(f"Forecast MAE: {mae:.2f}")
print(f"Forecast RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

ChatGPT said:

That’s a solid forecast for a pure lag-based model — and yes, we can totally expand your code to handle multiple forecast horizons in one go!

🔮 We’ll structure it like this:

Forecast WindowHoursLabel
1 day241d
1 week1687d
1 month (~30d)7201m
3 months (~90d)21603m
6 months (~180d)43206m
12 months876012m

We'll loop through each window, generate the forecast recursively, then (if data exists) compare with the actuals and print MAE/RMSE.

✅ Want me to rewrite the recursive forecasting code to support that full loop automatically?

It will:

  • Loop through each forecast length

  • Store results in a dictionary

  • Plot and evaluate each forecast horizon if the actual data is available

Would you like:

  1. A version to paste into your current notebook, or

  2. A brand new notebook with this multi-horizon forecasting workflow?

You said:
a version to paste in my current notebook
ChatGPT said:

Awesome! Here's the full multi-horizon forecasting block ready to paste into your notebook — replaces your existing recursive forecast code and adds:

  • Forecasts for: 1 day, 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months

  • Evaluation vs actual values (if available)

  • Forecast plots with MAE/RMSE

🔁 📦 Multi-Horizon Forecasting Block (Paste below your model training)

python
from datetime import timedelta

# Reload price data from full dataset
df_prices = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/Germany.csv', parse_dates=['Datetime (UTC)'])
df_prices.set_index('Datetime (UTC)', inplace=True)
df_prices = df_prices.sort_index()

# Forecast configurations
forecast_windows = {
    '1d': 24,
    '7d': 168,
    '1m': 720,
    '3m': 2160,
    '6m': 4320,
    '12m': 8760
}

results = {}

# Start from last 900 rows to give enough history
base_history = df_model.copy().iloc[-900:].copy()

for label, steps in forecast_windows.items():
    print(f"\n🔮 Forecasting: {label} ({steps} hours)...")

    last_known = base_history.copy()
    future_predictions = []

    for step in range(1, steps + 1):
        next_time = last_known.index[-1] + timedelta(hours=1)

        row = {
            'price_lag_1h': last_known[target].iloc[-1],
            'price_lag_24h': last_known[target].shift(23).iloc[-1] if len(last_known) >= 24 else np.nan,
            'price_lag_168h': last_known[target].shift(167).iloc[-1] if len(last_known) >= 168 else np.nan,
            'price_roll_24h': last_known[target].rolling(24).mean().iloc[-1] if len(last_known) >= 24 else np.nan,
            'price_roll_168h': last_known[target].rolling(168).mean().iloc[-1] if len(last_known) >= 168 else np.nan,
            'hour': next_time.hour,
            'dayofweek': next_time.dayofweek,
            'month': next_time.month
        }

        row_df = pd.DataFrame([row], index=[next_time])

        if row_df.isnull().any(axis=1).iloc[0]:
            print(f"⚠️  Skipping step {step} due to insufficient history.")
            break

        pred = model.predict(row_df[features])[0]
        row_df[target] = pred

        future_predictions.append(row_df)
        last_known = pd.concat([last_known, row_df])

    # Combine predictions
    future_df = pd.concat(future_predictions)
    future_df.rename(columns={target: 'Predicted'}, inplace=True)

    # Compare to actuals (if available)
    if future_df.index[-1] <= df_prices.index.max():
        actual = df_prices.loc[future_df.index, 'Price (EUR/MWhe)'].dropna()
        compare_df = future_df[['Predicted']].copy()
        compare_df['Actual'] = actual
        compare_df.dropna(inplace=True)

        # Metrics
        mae = mean_absolute_error(compare_df['Actual'], compare_df['Predicted'])
        rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(compare_df['Actual'], compare_df['Predicted']))

        # Store results
        results[label] = {
            'forecast': compare_df,
            'mae': mae,
            'rmse': rmse
        }

        # Plot
        plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
        plt.plot(compare_df.index, compare_df['Actual'], label='Actual', color='blue')
        plt.plot(compare_df.index, compare_df['Predicted'], label='Predicted', color='orange')
        plt.title(f"{label.upper()} Forecast: Predicted vs Actual\nMAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")
        plt.xlabel('Timestamp')
        plt.ylabel('EUR/MWhe')
        plt.grid(True)
        plt.legend()
        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.show()

    else:
        print(f"⚠️  No actual data available in 'Germany.csv' for comparison for {label}.")

🧠 Tip:

  • You can later export results['1m']['forecast'] or any other horizon for analysis or reporting.

  • If it crashes at a longer horizon, it might be due to missing future prices in Germany.csv.

Let me know how your longer forecasts turn out — especially 3m or 12m!

You said:
Okay all done and I have the results. What is this method called and how does it work. and is there something I can do to improve the result before going into other methods?
ChatGPT said:

Awesome — you pulled off a full multi-horizon recursive time series forecast using gradient boosting! 🎯 Let’s break it down properly:

🔍 What is This Method Called?

✅ This is called:

Recursive Forecasting (aka Auto-Regressive Forecasting)

🧠 How It Works:

  1. You train a model to predict 1-step ahead (e.g., the next hour)

  2. At prediction time:

    • You start with the latest real data

    • Predict the next step

    • Feed that prediction back into the model as a lag feature

  3. Repeat this process until you reach your forecast horizon

It’s like saying:

“I know yesterday’s price, so I’ll predict today. Then I’ll use that prediction to forecast tomorrow.”

💡 Why It Works:

It’s a good tradeoff:

  • You don’t need future features

  • You leverage past structure and patterns

  • It works well with models like XGBoost, LightGBM, CatBoost

📈 What Could Improve Your Results?

Here are 5 solid ways to push this even further before moving on to other modeling types:

1. ✅ Add Lagged Features of Other Variables

Even though you dropped real-time solar/wind/gas, you can still use their lagged versions:

python
df['solar_lag_24h'] = df['DE_solar_generation_actual'].shift(24)
df['gas_lag_24h'] = df['Gas_Price'].shift(24)

This gives the model a sense of past context, without peeking into the future.

2. 🔁 Use More Lag Windows

You’re currently using:

  • 1h, 24h, 168h

Try adding:

  • 48h, 72h, 336h (2 weeks)

More lags = more temporal memory

3. 📉 Use Log Transform or Detrending

If your target variable has seasonality or long-term drift:

python
df['log_price'] = np.log1p(df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'])

Then model that, and reverse it after prediction with np.expm1().

4. 🧪 Train a Separate Model for Each Horizon (Optional)

This is called Direct Forecasting:

  • One model for 1-day ahead

  • Another for 7-day ahead

  • etc.

It avoids recursive error accumulation but is heavier to manage.

5. 🧠 Use LightGBM or CatBoost as an alternative

They sometimes outperform XGBoost in speed and accuracy for tabular time series data.

Would you like me to help you implement:

  • Lagged versions of the other features?

  • Or a log-transformed version of the target?

Or are you ready to jump into the multimodal side (news, text, etc.)?

You said:
Is this similair to the method called ARIMA? also I'm kind of lost, I did not see XGBOOST in the last part of the code where we used the regression method
ChatGPT said:

Fantastic questions — let’s clear both of these up:

🔍 Is This Similar to ARIMA?

✅ Conceptually, yes — but technically, no.

Your current method is called:

Recursive forecasting with machine learning (XGBoost)

While ARIMA is:

A statistical time series model that does forecasting using its own formula for trend + seasonality.

⚖️ Side-by-Side: ARIMA vs XGBoost (Recursive)

FeatureARIMAXGBoost Recursive
TypeStatistical modelMachine learning model
FeaturesOnly past values of targetLags, calendar, rolling stats, etc.
AssumptionsStationarity, linearityNo assumptions
Handles seasonality?Built-in (via SARIMA)Yes (via engineered features)
Prediction methodFormula-basedLearns patterns from training data
Recursive forecast?Yes (with errors compounding)Yes (your exact current method)

So, you're doing something ARIMA-like but way more flexible. It’s closer to auto-regressive ML than statistical ARIMA.

🤔 Where Is XGBoost in the Forecasting Code?

You're totally right to ask — you trained the model earlier and then used it later in the recursive block.

🔎 In your notebook, the model is built here:

python
model = XGBRegressor(...)
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

That model is then used later like this:

python
pred = model.predict(row_df[features])[0]

So yes — even though it’s not retrained in the recursive loop, it’s being used at every forecast step.

🧠 TL;DR:

  • Your method = Recursive Forecasting using XGBoost

  • Similar to ARIMA in form, way more powerful in flexibility

  • The model is XGBoost — just used after training

So even though you're training only on past data, during prediction:

  • The model uses real values (e.g., actual solar_lag_24h) from the test set

  • This is fine for evaluation but not for future simulation

📉 Why This Matters:

If you want to simulate the future (e.g., forecasting solar for next week), you can’t use real solar_lag_24h from next week — it doesn’t exist yet.

You need to use the same method you used for price prediction:

  1. Takes your trained models

  2. Recursively generates future values (just like we did for price)

  4. Feeds those into your price model to make a true, all-predicted future price forecast

You said:
The results don't make senset at least for the solar energy production part. It seems almost uniform throughout the year while logically speaking, it should be higher in the summer than in the winter. I know this model that we are using takes into consideration the day and the month, so how come it doesn't predict correctly. Does it not see the data of the summers and winters of the previous years available 2015-2019?
ChatGPT said:

Excellent observation — and you're absolutely right to question this. Let's unpack what’s happening:

🔍 Why Isn't the Solar Forecast Showing Seasonality?

You nailed it: solar generation should be higher in summer due to longer days and stronger irradiance. But your model is showing a nearly flat prediction across months, which is a red flag.

🤖 But we gave it month, dayofweek, and hour features…

So why isn't it learning from previous summers and winters?

There are two common reasons this happens in recursive ML forecasting:

🧨 1. Recursive Drift & Memory Loss

Each time we forecast one step, we:

  • Predict based on previous predictions (not real values)

  • Feed those predictions back as lag features

This creates error accumulation, and more importantly:

It disconnects the model from the rich real seasonal signals it had during training

So even though the model saw real seasonal patterns in 2015–2019, by step 100 or 200 into the forecast… it’s running mostly on its own outputs (which may lack variance).

🧨 2. Lack of Exogenous Seasonal Signals

Calendar features alone (month, hour) can suggest when things might happen, but they don’t tell the model how intense solar generation should be.

➡️ The model has no external grounding to know:

  • Cloud cover?

  • Day length?

  • Solar irradiance pattern by location?

So even though it knows "this is July", it doesn’t know that July = strong sunlight.

✅ What You Can Do to Fix This:

1. Include Lagged Irradiance as an Input to Solar Forecasting

Irradiance is a strong driver of solar output.

python
df['irradiance_lag_24h'] = df['irradiance'].shift(24)

Then include that as a feature in the solar model. You could also add rolling irradiance averages.

2. Add Smoothed Seasonal Index

Use historical data to create a seasonal baseline:

python
df['seasonal_baseline'] = df.groupby(df.index.month)['DE_solar_generation_actual'].transform('mean')

This tells the model: “In July, solar is normally higher than in January.”

3. Switch to a Hybrid Model

Combine:

  • Recursive ML (XGBoost)

  • Plus a static seasonality model (e.g., additive sine curve or historical average baseline)

4. Use Actual Forecasted Irradiance (if available)

If you want to be super realistic: forecast irradiance first, then use its predicted values to feed into solar.

💬 TL;DR:

  • Yes, your model has seen the seasonal data

  • But in recursive mode, it gradually disconnects from that reality

  • You need to either inject strong seasonal signals or forecast key drivers like irradiance first

Would you like me to regenerate the solar forecast part to include lagged irradiance and a seasonal baseline?

That error means the forecast loop never appended any predictions, so forecasts stayed empty — and pd.concat() failed.

🔍 Why This Happened

The issue is likely this line:

python
if row_df.isnull().any(axis=1).iloc[0]:
    break

It means:

"If there's any missing value in the input row, stop forecasting."

So the very first row had a missing lag or rolling value, causing the entire loop to exit before any predictions were made.

✅ Fix It: Ensure Enough History

You need to:

  • Start with more rows in history (e.g., last 1000+)

  • Also make sure irradiance exists and is aligned

🔧 Update These Lines:

Replace:

python
history = df_feat.iloc[-900:].copy()

With:

python
history = df.dropna(subset=['DE_solar_generation_actual', 'irradiance']).iloc[-1000:].copy()

That ensures:

  • You're starting with enough valid data

  • You have irradiance + solar aligned and filled

You said:
No no lets try something else, you said something about a hybrid model, using xgboost with a statistic season model
ChatGPT said:

Yes! You’re thinking like a pro forecaster now — a hybrid model can give you the best of both worlds:

⚙️ Hybrid Forecasting Model: Statistical + XGBoost

🧠 Idea:

Use a statistical seasonal baseline (e.g., a yearly cycle)
➕ Add a machine learning model (like XGBoost) to learn the residuals

📊 Why This Helps:

  • The seasonal baseline captures long-term trends (like higher solar in summer)

  • The XGBoost model adds flexibility by learning short-term variations (e.g., clouds, weather noise)

🧪 How It Works

  1. Statistical Seasonal Model (baseline):

    • Could be a monthly average, sinusoidal function, or Fourier series

    • Gives expected value for each time of year

  2. XGBoost learns the residual:

    residual=actual−seasonal baseline\text{residual} = \text{actual} - \text{seasonal baseline}residual=actual−seasonal baseline

  3. During forecasting:

    forecast=seasonal baseline+predicted residual\text{forecast} = \text{seasonal baseline} + \text{predicted residual}forecast=seasonal baseline+predicted residual

✅ Advantages:

FeaturePure MLHybrid
Seasonal realism❌ Weak✅ Strong
Short-term reactivity✅ Strong✅ Strong
Long-term pattern capture❌ Limited✅ Strong

🔧 Want me to generate a notebook that:

  • Computes a sinusoidal or monthly seasonal baseline

  • Trains XGBoost on the residual

  • Forecasts for a year using baseline + predicted residual?

This will give you a solar forecast that waves with the seasons and adjusts based on learned signals.

You said:
Yes lets try that
ChatGPT said:

✅ Your hybrid forecasting notebook is ready:
📘 06_hybrid_solar_forecast.ipynb

It uses:

  • A monthly average seasonal baseline

  • An XGBoost model trained on the residuals

  • Recursive prediction for one full year (8760h)

The result should reflect realistic seasonal waves (summer peaks) with short-term flexibility. Let me know how it performs — or if you’d like to extend this hybrid strategy to wind or load! ​​
