ChatGPT said:

Ah, that error is telling us that some of the feature columns you're trying to use in the energy price model — like 'DE_solar_generation_actual', 'Gas_Price', etc. — aren’t present in model_data, which only contains price and lagged/calculated columns.

✅ Here's why it failed:

We tried to build this:

python
X = model_data[['lag_1h', 'lag_24h', 'lag_168h', 'hour', 'dayofweek', 'month'] + features_to_forecast]

But model_data doesn't have those feature columns like Gas_Price — they’re in the main df, not in this extracted subset.

🔧 Fix: Merge back the input features from df

Right before we create X and y, add this line:

python
model_data = model_data.merge(df[features_to_forecast], left_index=True, right_index=True)

So this block becomes:

python
model_data = df[['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].copy()
model_data['lag_1h'] = model_data['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(1)
model_data['lag_24h'] = model_data['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24)
model_data['lag_168h'] = model_data['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(168)
model_data['hour'] = model_data.index.hour
model_data['dayofweek'] = model_data.index.dayofweek
model_data['month'] = model_data.index.month

# 🔧 merge back input features
model_data = model_data.merge(df[features_to_forecast], left_index=True, right_index=True)

model_data = model_data.dropna()
X = model_data[['lag_1h', 'lag_24h', 'lag_168h', 'hour', 'dayofweek', 'month'] + features_to_forecast]
y = model_data['Price (EUR/MWhe)']

Try that out and let me know how the 1-week forecast performs now! Want me to patch this into the notebook file for you?

You said:
The resultss were bad: MAE: 29.21, RMSE: 37.94
ChatGPT said:

That’s definitely a big miss — let’s troubleshoot step-by-step and then work toward tightening it up.

🔍 Why the Results Might Be Off

Here are the most likely reasons your model gave high errors:

1. Recursive error compounding

Each feature (solar, wind, gas, etc.) was predicted recursively, so:

  • Small inaccuracies in inputs → amplify across time

  • Those noisy inputs then get fed into the price model

🔁 You’re stacking error on top of error.

2. Price model never saw predicted-style data

Your price model was trained on real features, but tested on predicted ones. That mismatch throws it off:

  • It learned clean signals

  • Now it gets noisy ones

This is known as covariate shift in time series ML.

3. Some feature forecasts might be unstable

Some input features (e.g., wind or temperature) might have:

  • Unrealistic values

  • Missing seasonality

  • Negative values that shouldn’t happen

And the price model can’t make sense of those.

✅ What You Can Do to Improve Results

Here are two key strategies:

🧪 Option 1: Include input forecast noise during training

Simulate the real-life scenario:

  • Train the price model on predicted inputs rather than perfect ones

  • This teaches it to be robust to input noise

✅ I can help you set that up.

🧪 Option 2: Retrain price model using lagged price + calendar only

Drop all feature inputs. Just focus on:

  • Price lag 1h, 24h, 168h

  • Hour, day, month

✅ This worked much better before — do a quick comparison.

🧠 Bonus: Evaluate individual input forecast quality

Want to test which feature forecast might be the culprit?

  • Plot predicted vs actual for solar, wind, gas

  • You might find one is wildly inaccurate

Would you like to:

  1. Retrain the price model with fewer inputs (calendar + price lags only)?

  2. Simulate noisy training by injecting predicted inputs into training?

  3. Inspect feature forecast quality?

Pick one and I’ll help you jump into it 🚀

You said:
Inspect feature forecast quality
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — let’s break it down! You’ve already recursively predicted 7 days of:

  • Solar

  • Wind

  • Load

  • Irradiance

  • Temperature

  • Oil

  • Gas

We’ll now compare each forecast against the actual values (from your original dataset) to see:

✅ Which features are accurate
⚠️ Which are drifting or noisy
❌ Which are hurting your price model

🔍 Here's a block of code to paste into your notebook:

python
# 🔍 Evaluate feature forecasts
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error

for feature, pred_df in input_predictions.items():
    print(f"\n📊 Evaluating forecast for: {feature}")
    
    # Get actual values for the forecasted timestamps
    actual = df.loc[pred_df.index, feature].dropna()
    forecast = pred_df[feature].reindex(actual.index)
    
    # Align lengths
    if len(actual) == 0 or len(forecast) == 0:
        print("⚠️ No data available for comparison.")
        continue

    # Metrics
    mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, forecast)
    rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, forecast))
    
    print(f"MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")
    
    # Plot
    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 4))
    plt.plot(actual.index, actual, label="Actual")
    plt.plot(forecast.index, forecast, label="Predicted", alpha=0.8)
    plt.title(f"{feature} - Actual vs Predicted (7 Day Forecast)")
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

📈 This will:

  • Loop over each feature

  • Plot actual vs predicted values for the 7-day horizon

  • Print MAE and RMSE for each one

Let me know which ones perform worst — we can retrain or refine just those forecasts. Want help fixing the worst offenders once you check them?

You said:
Just realized this won't work because I only have price data after 2019. So lets start from scratch again. Let's take another aproach. I am at time t, I want my outputs to be to be price at t+1 .... t+168, and then my inputs would be all the features at time t, t-1, t-2 .... t-x where x is a reasonable number of steps backward that we have to figure out. What do you think of this approach
ChatGPT said:

That's an excellent approach — you're essentially framing the problem as a true multi-output forecasting task, where:

  • Inputs: past values of price and other features at time t, t−1, ..., t−x

  • Outputs: future prices at time t+1, t+2, ..., t+168

🔍 Why This Works Better:

  • It avoids recursive errors by predicting the entire future horizon in one shot

  • Inputs are fully available at prediction time

  • It’s ideal for short- to medium-term energy market forecasting

🔧 Key Design Decisions

1. Input window length x (past steps)

  • A typical choice: x = 168 (1 week of hourly data)

  • You could try different lengths: 24, 72, 168, etc., and compare performance

2. Features

  • Use past values of:

    • Price (EUR/MWhe)

    • Solar, Wind, Load, Irradiance, Temperature, Gas, Oil

  • Add calendar features at time t: hour, day of week, month

3. Model

  • Use a multi-output regressor like:

    • MultiOutputRegressor(XGBRegressor(...))

    • Or train 168 separate models (one per future hour)

🧪 Want Me To Build You a New Notebook?

I can generate:

  • A clean supervised dataset: X = past data, y = future prices

  • Multi-output forecast with 168 targets

  • Metrics + plot

You said:
The model is running for 30 mins so far. Is it normal, if so in the meantime we can start looking up data for the next part which is about the news
ChatGPT said:

Yes, it’s totally normal — training MultiOutputRegressor with 168 separate regressors (one per hour) can be computationally intensive, especially with XGBoost and long input vectors. Let it cook 🧠🔥.

📰 In the meantime: Let's gather news data

You're aiming to capture how news affects energy prices — so we'll want:

✅ Topics to track:

  • Renewable energy (e.g., solar, wind, hydrogen)

  • Fossil fuels (e.g., oil, gas)

  • Energy markets and infrastructure

  • Political events (wars, sanctions, OPEC decisions)

  • Environmental disasters or policy changes

🔎 Free News Data Sources for Energy Topics

Here are options depending on your preferred format:

1. GDELT Project (Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone)

  • Massive archive of news events from around the world

  • Keyword filterable (e.g., "energy", "gas" + "Germany")

  • Includes tone/sentiment scores

  • https://www.gdeltproject.org/

2. NewsAPI.org

  • Free tier lets you search recent headlines from major sources

  • Easy to filter by keyword ("energy", "renewables")

  • https://newsapi.org/

3. European Energy Exchange (EEX) / ENTSO-E Reports

  • Include policy updates, events, and press releases

  • Germany-focused

  • https://www.entsoe.eu/news/

4. Google News RSS + Scraping

  • Use RSS feeds for energy-related terms

  • Scrape headlines/timestamps to build your dataset

💡 Would you like to:

  • Use a script to download headlines and timestamps from a source like NewsAPI or GDELT?

  • Or just browse manually and label events for now?

Let me know and I’ll prep the best starting point for you.

You said:
no give me a script
ChatGPT said:

Got it — here’s a Python script that uses NewsAPI to collect news articles about energy. It pulls:

  • 🕒 Date

  • 📰 Title

  • 🌐 Source

  • 🔗 URL
    ...and saves everything into a CSV.

✅ Step 1: Get a free API key

Go to https://newsapi.org/register
Create an account → copy your API key.

✅ Step 2: Python script to get energy news

python
import requests
import pandas as pd
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

# 🔑 Replace with your actual NewsAPI key
API_KEY = 'YOUR_NEWSAPI_KEY_HERE'

# 🗞 Keywords to search (edit as needed)
QUERY = 'energy OR gas OR oil OR renewable OR electricity OR war OR boycott'
FROM_DATE = (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=30)).strftime('%Y-%m-%d')  # last 30 days
TO_DATE = datetime.now().strftime('%Y-%m-%d')

# 📦 Where to store results
articles = []

# Loop through paginated results (NewsAPI returns 100 max per page)
for page in range(1, 6):  # Adjust range for more pages (max ~500 articles)
    url = (
        f'https://newsapi.org/v2/everything?q={QUERY}&from={FROM_DATE}&to={TO_DATE}&language=en'
        f'&sortBy=publishedAt&pageSize=100&page={page}&apiKey={API_KEY}'
    )

    response = requests.get(url)
    data = response.json()

    if data.get("status") != "ok":
        print(f"Error: {data.get('message')}")
        break

    for article in data['articles']:
        articles.append({
            'publishedAt': article['publishedAt'],
            'title': article['title'],
            'source': article['source']['name'],
            'url': article['url']
        })

    if len(data['articles']) < 100:
        break  # No more articles

# 🔽 Save to CSV
df = pd.DataFrame(articles)
df['publishedAt'] = pd.to_datetime(df['publishedAt'])
df.to_csv('energy_news_articles.csv', index=False)

print(f"✅ Saved {len(df)} articles to energy_news_articles.csv")

🧠 Tips:

  • You can later join this with your energy price data using publishedAt → hourly alignment

  • You can add sentiment analysis using libraries like TextBlob, VADER, or transformers

Want me to help with:

  • Sentiment tagging?

  • Keyword filtering by country (e.g., Germany)?

  • Aligning news with your energy price timeline?

Just say the word 🔎

✅ Best Option for Historical News (2015–2019):

🔍 GDELT Project

The Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone is:

  • Free

  • Massive (covers global news since 1979)

  • Includes timestamped news events with topics + tone

✅ What You Get:

Each GDELT entry contains:

  • 📆 Date/time

  • 🗞 News headline

  • 🌎 Location (country, region)

  • 🎯 Themes (like “ENERGY_CRISIS” or “ELECTRICITY”)

  • 😡 Sentiment score

  • ENERGY

  • GAS

  • FUEL

  • OIL

You said:
go ahead
ChatGPT said:

✅ Your script is ready:
📄 download_gdelt_energy_germany_2015_2019.py

📦 What it does:

  • Downloads GDELT GKG files for each day from 2015–2019

  • Filters articles that:

    • Mention energy-related themes (ENERGY, GAS, OIL, etc.)

    • Are tagged with Germany in the location

  • Saves everything to: gdelt_energy_news/energy_news_germany_2015_2019.csv

▶️ To run:

bash
python download_gdelt_energy_germany_2015_2019.py

⚠️ It may take a while — you’re scanning ~3,500+ zipped files.

You said:
is it okay if i run it while the xgboost is running, might my computer crash? I have a 10 year old core i7 computer with 16 gb of RAM
ChatGPT said:

Great question — and definitely smart to be cautious, especially with a 10-year-old machine running heavy stuff. Here's a quick breakdown:

🧠 What's Happening:

  • XGBoost MultiOutputRegressor is already eating CPU and memory

  • The GDELT script downloads and decompresses ZIPs, parses large CSVs, and builds a growing DataFrame

⚠️ Potential Risks on Your System:

❗ CPU Overload

  • Both tasks are CPU-heavy → might spike to 100% usage

  • Could slow your machine to a crawl or cause overheating

❗ RAM Pressure

  • 16GB is decent, but:

    • XGBoost already consumes a chunk

    • Pandas + decompression + storing GDELT frames might push you over

❗ Disk I/O

  • Writing lots of GDELT files while XGBoost writes model artifacts may bog down disk access

✅ Safe Alternatives:

  1. Wait for XGBoost to finish, then run the GDELT script

  2. Or, if you're impatient:

    • Kill browser tabs

    • Pause unnecessary programs (VSCode, etc.)

    • Run the script with a limit (e.g., just 1 month of GDELT to test)

⚙️ Tip: To test the script without crashing your system

Change this part:

python
start_date = datetime(2015, 1, 1)
end_date = datetime(2019, 12, 31)

To:

python
start_date = datetime(2015, 1, 1)
end_date = datetime(2015, 1, 3)

Just 2–3 days = light test.

Want me to modify the script for “safe mode” testing first?

You said:
No I'll just wait, can you estimate the time for xgboost to finish?
ChatGPT said:

Fair choice — playing it safe is smart here. As for estimating XGBoost's training time in MultiOutputRegressor, here's a breakdown to help you gauge the wait:

⏱️ Estimating Time Remaining

📊 What you're training:

  • 168 separate XGBoost regressors

  • Each gets:

    • ~168 input features × ~30,000+ training samples (depending on your dataset)

    • 100 trees (estimators)

⚙️ Your system:

  • ~10-year-old Core i7

  • 16 GB RAM (decent, but not cutting edge)

  • Single-threaded training (default unless parallelized)

🧠 Ballpark Estimates (per model):

Model TypeEstimated per-model timeTotal (168 models)
Light model (few features, fast disk)~5–10 sec~15–30 minutes
Medium (XGBoost + 1 week lag × 8 features)~10–30 sec~30–80 minutes
Heavy (slow disk, CPU throttling)~60+ sec2+ hours

🚀 Tips:

  • If it's already been 30+ minutes, you're likely halfway or more there

  • The training time should plateau soon — most of the work is front-loaded

🧩 You can check current CPU usage:

  • Windows: Open Task Manager → check Python CPU %

  • Linux/macOS: Run top or htop

If Python is still maxing out a core, it's still training.

Let me know when it finishes and we can jump straight into visualizing or improving results 💪

ChatGPT said:

Yes — I’ve got your setup in memory 🍏🍎 Here's what I know from earlier:

📁 Your energy price data file:

  • 📄 Germany.csv

  • 📂 Located in: data/raw/

✅ Goal:

You want to compare the 168-output XGBoost forecast with your recursive model, both predicting:

  • The first 168 hours of 2020

  • Using the same actual values for comparison

🧩 Here’s a code snippet to extract actual values for that period:

python
# Load full price data (raw file)
df_full = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/Germany.csv', parse_dates=['Datetime (UTC)'])
df_full.set_index('Datetime (UTC)', inplace=True)
df_full.sort_index(inplace=True)

# Extract the ground truth for the first week of 2020
start = '2020-01-01 00:00:00'
end = '2020-01-07 23:00:00'
actual_price_week = df_full.loc[start:end, 'Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# Make sure it’s 168 rows
print("✅ Actual price length:", len(actual_price_week))

🧠 You can now compare:

  • y_pred[0] from your multi-output model

  • With actual_price_week.values

If you’d like, I can also give you a full MAE/RMSE/plot block side-by-side. Want that too?

You said:
Yes please
ChatGPT said:

Here you go — a full evaluation block to compare your predicted prices (from y_pred[0]) with the true prices for the first week of 2020 from Germany.csv:

✅ Drop this block at the end of your notebook:

python
# 📥 Load true prices from Germany.csv
df_true = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/Germany.csv', parse_dates=['Datetime (UTC)'])
df_true.set_index('Datetime (UTC)', inplace=True)
df_true.sort_index(inplace=True)

# 🎯 Actual price for the first week of 2020
start = '2020-01-01 00:00:00'
end = '2020-01-07 23:00:00'
actual_price_week = df_true.loc[start:end, 'Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# ✅ Compare to your model's first prediction (y_pred[0])
predicted_price_week = y_pred[0]

# 🧮 Compute error metrics
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error
mae = mean_absolute_error(actual_price_week, predicted_price_week)
rmse = mean_squared_error(actual_price_week, predicted_price_week, squared=False)

print(f"📊 MAE: {mae:.2f}")
print(f"📊 RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

# 📈 Plot comparison
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(actual_price_week.index, actual_price_week.values, label='Actual')
plt.plot(actual_price_week.index, predicted_price_week, label='Predicted')
plt.title("Energy Price Forecast (Multi-output XGBoost) vs Actual — Jan 1–7, 2020")
plt.xlabel("Date")
plt.ylabel("Price (EUR/MWhe)")
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

This will:

  • Align the timestamps perfectly

  • Compute MAE and RMSE

  • Give you a side-by-side visual of predicted vs actual 📈

Let me know if you want to repeat this for your recursive model’s output too!

You said:
mean_squared_error is not available in the version im using
ChatGPT said:

No problem — if mean_squared_error(..., squared=False) isn’t available (likely an older scikit-learn version), you can manually compute RMSE like this:

✅ Replace this line:

python
rmse = mean_squared_error(actual_price_week, predicted_price_week, squared=False)

🧮 With this:

python
rmse = np.sqrt(np.mean((actual_price_week.values - predicted_price_week) ** 2))

🔁 Full adjusted block:

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error
import numpy as np

mae = mean_absolute_error(actual_price_week, predicted_price_week)
rmse = np.sqrt(np.mean((actual_price_week.values - predicted_price_week) ** 2))

print(f"📊 MAE: {mae:.2f}")
print(f"📊 RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

Let me know what the numbers turn out to be — we’ll see who wins: XGBoost direct or recursive 🥊📈

You said:
something seems off, did you run the model with the last week of 2019 as input?
ChatGPT said:

Ah — great catch. You're totally right to question this.

By default, the notebook used train_test_split(..., shuffle=False), which likely placed the last portion of your dataset (2019) in the test set — but:

✅ The first prediction y_pred[0] may not actually correspond to Jan 1–7, 2020
❌ So comparing it to that week from Germany.csv might not be valid

🔍 What likely happened:

  • You trained on ~80% of the dataset

  • The final 20% was used for testing

  • y_test[0] → could be anywhere in mid/late 2019, not 2020

✅ How to fix it — and test on Jan 1–7, 2020 only:

We’ll change this:

python
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, shuffle=False)

To instead manually select:

  • Last 168 steps that end right before 2020

  • Forecast the next 168 hours

🧩 Updated logic:

python
# 🧠 Find the row where 2020 begins
target_start = df.index.get_loc('2020-01-01 00:00:00')
input_lag = 168
forecast_horizon = 168

# 🎯 Index just before the prediction window
i = target_start - forecast_horizon

# Recreate input window for 168h before
X_test_2020 = df[feature_cols].iloc[i - input_lag:i].values.flatten().reshape(1, -1)

# Predict using trained model
y_pred_2020 = model.predict(X_test_2020)[0]

# Get actual prices from raw file for Jan 1–7, 2020
actual_price_week = df_true.loc['2020-01-01 00:00:00':'2020-01-07 23:00:00', 'Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# Now run comparison/plot code with:
# y_pred_2020 vs actual_price_week

Would you like me to send the full corrected block including the plot + metric code with this update applied?

You said:
yes please
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely — here’s the fully corrected version to evaluate your 168-hour forecast starting exactly on Jan 1, 2020, using the last week of 2019 as input:

✅ Drop this into your notebook after training the model:

python
# 🧠 Step 1: Set up
input_lag = 168
forecast_horizon = 168
feature_cols = [
    'Price (EUR/MWhe)',
    'DE_solar_generation_actual', 'DE_wind_generation_actual',
    'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency', 'Gas_Price', 'Oil_Price',
    'irradiance', 'temperature'
]

# 📥 Load raw full price data
df_true = pd.read_csv('../data/raw/Germany.csv', parse_dates=['Datetime (UTC)'])
df_true.set_index('Datetime (UTC)', inplace=True)
df_true.sort_index(inplace=True)

# 📊 Reload cleaned data (with all features)
df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)
df.sort_index(inplace=True)

# 🎯 Locate prediction start: 2020-01-01 00:00:00
target_start = df.index.get_loc('2020-01-01 00:00:00')
i = target_start - forecast_horizon

# 🧠 Build input window from last 168h of 2019
X_test_2020 = df[feature_cols].iloc[i - input_lag:i].values.flatten().reshape(1, -1)

# 🔮 Forecast
y_pred_2020 = model.predict(X_test_2020)[0]

# 🎯 Actual prices from raw file
actual_price_week = df_true.loc['2020-01-01 00:00:00':'2020-01-07 23:00:00', 'Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# 🧮 Metrics
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error
import numpy as np
mae = mean_absolute_error(actual_price_week.values, y_pred_2020)
rmse = np.sqrt(np.mean((actual_price_week.values - y_pred_2020) ** 2))

print(f"📊 MAE (Jan 1–7, 2020): {mae:.2f}")
print(f"📊 RMSE (Jan 1–7, 2020): {rmse:.2f}")

# 📈 Plot
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(actual_price_week.index, actual_price_week.values, label='Actual')
plt.plot(actual_price_week.index, y_pred_2020, label='Predicted')
plt.title("📈 Energy Price Forecast vs Actual (Jan 1–7, 2020)")
plt.xlabel("Date")
plt.ylabel("Price (EUR/MWhe)")
plt.grid(True)
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

This guarantees:

  • 📦 The forecast starts on exactly Jan 1, 2020

  • 📊 The input window is 100% historical (not leaked from the test set)

  • 🧪 You can now compare this apples-to-apples with your recursive model

Let me know the results — or if you want to generate a similar forecast for another date range!

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for the screenshot — it reveals the issue clearly:

⚠️ Problem:

You're trying to access '2020-01-01 00:00:00', but your df.index ends on 2019-12-30 — the date you want is simply not there.

The timestamps in your DataFrame appear to be:

  • Timezone-aware (like 2019-12-30T01:00:00+0100)

  • Ending before 2020 starts

✅ Fix: Let’s use the last available timestamp

Instead of assuming '2020-01-01' exists, we’ll:

  1. Get the last valid datetime in the DataFrame

  2. Use that as our forecast anchor point

🔁 Drop-in Replacement Code:

python
# 🧠 Automatically determine the last available timestamp
last_timestamp = df.index.max()
print("📅 Last available data point:", last_timestamp)

# Use that as the anchor point for your test window
i = df.index.get_loc(last_timestamp)
X_test_final = df[feature_cols].iloc[i - input_lag:i].values.flatten().reshape(1, -1)

# Predict
y_pred_final = model.predict(X_test_final)[0]

# Plot vs actual from Germany.csv for same period
actual_price_final = df_true.loc[last_timestamp + pd.Timedelta(hours=1):last_timestamp + pd.Timedelta(hours=forecast_horizon), 'Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# Evaluate and plot
mae = mean_absolute_error(actual_price_final.values, y_pred_final[:len(actual_price_final)])
rmse = np.sqrt(np.mean((actual_price_final.values - y_pred_final[:len(actual_price_final)])**2))

print(f"📊 MAE: {mae:.2f}")
print(f"📊 RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
plt.plot(actual_price_final.index, actual_price_final.values, label='Actual')
plt.plot(actual_price_final.index, y_pred_final[:len(actual_price_final)], label='Predicted')
plt.title(f"📈 Energy Price Forecast vs Actual (Starting from {last_timestamp})")
plt.grid(True)
plt.xlabel("Date")
plt.ylabel("Price (EUR/MWhe)")
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

Let me know the result — or if you want to manually adjust the forecast start point instead!

You said:

ChatGPT said:

That error is super clear — you're referencing columns that don’t exist in your current DataFrame.

🔍 Problem:

Your feature_cols list includes:

python
'irradiance', 'temperature'

But your df (likely merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv) doesn’t have those columns — at least not under those exact names.

✅ Fix: Check the actual column names in your DataFrame

Here’s a quick command to run:

python
print(df.columns.tolist())

Look for:

  • Whether the columns exist at all

  • Whether they’re named slightly differently (e.g., 'DE_irradiance', 'air_temperature', etc.)

🔧 Then: Adjust feature_cols accordingly

Once you find the correct names, replace:

python
feature_cols = [
    'Price (EUR/MWhe)',
    'DE_solar_generation_actual', 'DE_wind_generation_actual',
    'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency', 'Gas_Price', 'Oil_Price',
    'irradiance', 'temperature'
]

With the actual names from your DataFrame.

You said:
The regressive forecast is still better than the 168 hour lag and 168 hour output method. But I built my whole hypothisis that the other features are useful information. How would you suggest I go about this issue so that the presentation is not weak
ChatGPT said:

This is such a sharp and insightful reflection — and it shows you're thinking like a real researcher, not just an engineer. Let’s break this down strategically:

🔍 The situation:

  • Your recursive (autoregressive) price model outperforms the multi-input direct forecast

  • Yet your hypothesis and project design emphasized that external features (solar, wind, etc.) add value

You’re worried the results might contradict the narrative — but that’s actually an opportunity if handled right.

🎯 Here's how to frame it powerfully in your presentation:

✅ 1. Acknowledge the outcome honestly

"Despite our initial hypothesis, recursive models using only past prices performed better than direct forecasting using full input features."

That makes you sound confident, data-driven, and objective.

✅ 2. Highlight the scientific value of the result

This is not a failure — it’s a discovery:

  • The energy price dynamics may be mostly explained by autoregressive structure

  • External features, although meaningful, may not improve predictive performance over short horizons (due to noise, lags, or weak correlation)

  • Multivariate models may be more useful for interpretability than for raw accuracy

✅ 3. Back your hypothesis with insights — not just results

Even if external features didn’t improve accuracy, you can still show:

  • Correlations (e.g. solar production vs. price → negative in daylight hours)

  • Lag relationships (e.g. temperature impacts next-day demand)

  • Plots of feature trends during major price peaks

That keeps your story alive — features do matter, just maybe not for this modeling window.

✅ 4. Reposition the result as “right tool for the job”

"Our study shows that for short-term (7-day) forecasting, autoregressive models dominate. But if we were forecasting further ahead, or using this in a policy context, external signals could become much more valuable."

This sounds smart and balanced — you're not discarding your hypothesis, you're refining it.

✅ 5. (Optional) Add a future direction slide

  • Explore whether feature importance grows with forecast horizon

  • Try ensembling: combine recursive + direct feature-based predictions

  • Use external features for anomaly detection, not prediction

💬 TL;DR Talking Point:

"Even though direct models using external variables didn’t outperform autoregressive ones, this tells us that energy prices carry strong internal momentum. External features may still offer interpretability, robustness, or long-range value — just not a short-term edge here."

Would you like help drafting a slide outline for this conclusion section or a few key sentences to say during your presentation?

You said:
In the meantime I have a new idea for the original model to see if we can perform better. What we did at some point was we forecasted the features and then used the values of the forecasted features in the model to find the price of energy right? but that is not what we did in the base model. What we did in thebase model was we found the ratio of the renewable energy sources as features. The total feature list was as follows: # Define features and target target = 'Price (EUR/MWhe)' features = [ 'DE_solar_generation_actual', 'DE_wind_generation_actual', 'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency', 'Gas_Price', 'Oil_Price', 'DE_radiation_direct_horizontal', 'DE_radiation_diffuse_horizontal', 'DE_temperature' ] # Lag features df['price_lag_1h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(1) df['price_lag_24h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24) df['price_lag_168h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(168) # Rolling averages df['price_roll_24h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(24).mean() df['price_roll_168h'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(168).mean() # Calendar features df['hour'] = df.index.hour df['dayofweek'] = df.index.dayofweek df['month'] = df.index.month # Ratio features df['solar_load_ratio'] = df['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency'] df['wind_load_ratio'] = df['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency'] # Final feature list features += [ 'price_lag_1h', 'price_lag_24h', 'price_lag_168h', 'price_roll_24h', 'price_roll_168h', 'hour', 'dayofweek', 'month', 'solar_load_ratio', 'wind_load_ratio' ] # Drop rows with missing values (due to shifting/rolling) df_model = df[features + ['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].dropna().... so how about we try to forecast all these features maybe a week forward (the first week of 2020) and use the forecasted features to find the energy prices for that week

  3. Predict energy prices

View as a scrollable element or open in a text editor. Adjust cell output settings...
ChatGPT said:

Thanks for the traceback — it clearly shows the issue:

⚠️ Problem:

You're trying to get actual values using:

python
actual = df[feature].loc[forecast_df.index]

But forecast_df.index contains timestamps like '2020-01-01 00:00:00', which may not exist in df.index because your dataset stops at '2019-12-30 00:00:00'.

✅ Fix:

We’re trying to evaluate the predictions for the last week of 2019, but we accidentally pulled the full forecast range (which includes Jan 2020).

🔁 Replace this block:

python
for feature, forecast_df in input_predictions.items():
    actual = df[feature].loc[forecast_df.index]

✅ With this:

python
# Only evaluate predictions from 2019-12-30 to 2019-12-31 (48 hours)
eval_start = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-30 00:00:00')
eval_end = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-31 23:00:00')

for feature, forecast_df in input_predictions.items():
    # Restrict forecasted values to time range in df
    valid_idx = forecast_df.index.intersection(df.index)
    pred = forecast_df.loc[valid_idx][feature]
    actual = df.loc[valid_idx, feature]

    mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, pred)
    rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, pred))

    print(f'{feature} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}')
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(actual.index, actual, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(pred.index, pred, label='Predicted')
    plt.title(feature)
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.show()

This will:

  • Limit evaluation to where you actually have real data

  • Avoid the KeyError

  • Plot and evaluate all 8 forecasted features

Let me know how the graphs look, and we’ll move to price prediction right after 🔮📈

python
# Only evaluate predictions from 2019-12-30 to 2019-12-31 (48 hours)
eval_start = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-30 00:00:00')
eval_end = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-31 23:00:00')

for feature, forecast_df in input_predictions.items():
    # Restrict forecasted values to time range in df
    valid_idx = forecast_df.index.intersection(df.index)
    pred = forecast_df.loc[valid_idx][feature]
    actual = df.loc[valid_idx, feature]

    mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, pred)
    rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, pred))

    print(f'{feature} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}')
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(actual.index, actual, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(pred.index, pred, label='Predicted')
    plt.title(feature)
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.show()

ChatGPT said:

Great debugging instinct — and yes, you're absolutely right to ask:

🔍 Does the code actually forecast the last week of December based on the week before?

Let’s break it down:

🧠 What’s Happening

The original code sets:

python
start_forecast = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-30 01:00:00')
forecast_steps = 168

This means it begins forecasting from Dec 30, 2019 @ 1:00 AM → well into Jan 6–7, 2020.

So when you try to evaluate forecast_df.index.intersection(df.index) — the intersection might be empty, because your df might stop before Jan 1, or include very little overlap.

✅ Solution Options

🔁 Option 1: Back up the forecast start time

Instead of forecasting into 2020, we shift start_forecast back to something like:

python
start_forecast = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-24 00:00:00')

This would allow evaluation over the last week of 2019 using predictions from the prior week.

🔎 Option 2: Restrict forecast just for testing purposes

Temporarily change:

python
forecast_steps = 48  # 2 days (e.g., Dec 30–31)

🔨 Option 3: Confirm data coverage manually

Run:

python
print(df.index.min(), df.index.max())

to confirm how far into 2020 the data actually goes.

🧠 Recommendation

If your goal is to validate forecast accuracy on the last week of 2019, update this line:

python
start_forecast = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-24 00:00:00')

And leave forecast_steps = 168 — this will simulate forecasting Dec 24–31 (last week of the year), which you have real data for.

Want me to regenerate the notebook with this change baked in?

--------------------------------------------------------------------------- ValueError Traceback (most recent call last) Cell In[5], line 11 8 pred = forecast_df.loc[valid_idx][feature] 9 actual = df.loc[valid_idx, feature] ---> 11 mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, pred) 12 rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, pred)) 14 print(f'{feature} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}') File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\_param_validation.py:216, in validate_params.<locals>.decorator.<locals>.wrapper(*args, **kwargs) 210 try: 211 with config_context( 212 skip_parameter_validation=( 213 prefer_skip_nested_validation or global_skip_validation 214 ) 215 ): --> 216 return func(*args, **kwargs) 217 except InvalidParameterError as e: 218 # When the function is just a wrapper around an estimator, we allow 219 # the function to delegate validation to the estimator, but we replace 220 # the name of the estimator by the name of the function in the error 221 # message to avoid confusion. 222 msg = re.sub( 223 r"parameter of \w+ must be", 224 f"parameter of {func.__qualname__} must be", ... 1134 ) 1136 if ensure_min_features > 0 and array.ndim == 2: 1137 n_features = array.shape[1] ValueError: Found array with 0 sample(s) (shape=(0,)) while a minimum of 1 is required. ChatGPT said:

That error confirms that the array is still empty — which means even after shifting the forecast window, there’s no overlap between your predicted timestamps and your actual df data.

Let’s fix this precisely and thoroughly:

✅ Diagnostic Step: Check what's going on

Paste this before the loop to inspect what’s available:

python
# Print what we're working with
for feature, forecast_df in input_predictions.items():
    print(f"{feature} forecast range: {forecast_df.index.min()} to {forecast_df.index.max()}")
    print(f"Original data range: {df[feature].index.min()} to {df[feature].index.max()}")
    print("-" * 60)

You’ll see whether the predicted timestamps and the actual data have any overlap at all.

🔧 Immediate Fix (Based on What We Know)

Try this robust replacement of Step 2 evaluation block:

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error

# Evaluate predictions where we have overlap with actuals
for feature, forecast_df in input_predictions.items():
    available_index = df.index.intersection(forecast_df.index)
    
    # Ensure we have overlap to evaluate
    if available_index.empty:
        print(f"⚠️ No overlapping data to evaluate for {feature}")
        continue

    actual = df.loc[available_index, feature]
    predicted = forecast_df.loc[available_index, feature]

    mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, predicted)
    rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, predicted))

    print(f'{feature} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}')

    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(actual.index, actual.values, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(predicted.index, predicted.values, label='Predicted')
    plt.title(f"{feature} Forecast Evaluation")
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.show()

This does 3 things:

  1. Dynamically finds overlapping timestamps

  2. Skips evaluation if there’s no overlap (instead of crashing)

  3. Gives you a per-feature assessment

Let me know what the printout says — and if you want me to reset the forecast window more precisely.

You said:
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error # Evaluate predictions where we have overlap with actuals for feature, forecast_df in input_predictions.items(): available_index = df.index.intersection(forecast_df.index) # Ensure we have overlap to evaluate if available_index.empty: print(f"⚠️ No overlapping data to evaluate for {feature}") continue actual = df.loc[available_index, feature] predicted = forecast_df.loc[available_index, feature] mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, predicted) rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, predicted)) print(f'{feature} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}') plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3)) plt.plot(actual.index, actual.values, label='Actual') plt.plot(predicted.index, predicted.values, label='Predicted') plt.title(f"{feature} Forecast Evaluation") plt.legend() plt.grid(True) plt.show()
ChatGPT said:

✅ Perfect — that’s exactly the right code block to use now.

With this version, you're:

  • ✅ Avoiding crashes from missing overlap

  • ✅ Evaluating only where you have matching timestamps

  • ✅ Getting clear visual and numerical results

🔍 Quick Tip:

If any features still say ⚠️ No overlapping data, it likely means your start_forecast is still set too far into 2020.

You can fix this by going to the top of your notebook (inside the recursive forecast loop) and changing this:

python
start_forecast = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-30 01:00:00')  # or something later

To this safer value:

python
start_forecast = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-24 00:00:00')

This guarantees the forecast stays in 2019 where your data is complete for evaluation.

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for sharing the updated code and error — you’re super close to having this work perfectly.

✅ What's wrong?

Your code defines this:

python
valid_idx = forecast_df.index.intersection(df.index)

But you're still getting:

plaintext
ValueError: Found array with 0 sample(s)

This means valid_idx is empty for at least one feature.

✅ Fix: Add a guard to skip empty arrays

Let’s make your loop bulletproof by:

  • Skipping features where valid_idx is empty

  • Logging which ones are affected

🔁 Replace your block with this version:

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error

# Only evaluate predictions from 2019-12-24 to 2019-12-31 (168 hours)
start_forecast = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-24 00:00:00')
eval_end = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-31 23:00:00')

for feature, forecast_df in input_predictions.items():
    # Restrict forecasted values to where actual data exists
    valid_idx = forecast_df.index.intersection(df.index)

    if len(valid_idx) == 0:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {feature}: no overlapping timestamps between predictions and actual data")
        continue

    pred = forecast_df.loc[valid_idx, feature]
    actual = df.loc[valid_idx, feature]

    if pred.empty or actual.empty:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {feature}: prediction or actual values are empty after filtering")
        continue

    mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, pred)
    rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, pred))

    print(f'{feature} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}')

    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(actual.index, actual, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(pred.index, pred, label='Predicted')
    plt.title(f"{feature} Forecast Evaluation")
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.show()

✅ What this version does:

  • Skips features that would crash the loop

  • Prints warnings to help you understand what’s missing

  • Continues to evaluate everything else properly

Let me know what the results look like — and we’ll move forward to the price prediction section right after 🔮📈

from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error # Only evaluate predictions from 2019-12-24 to 2019-12-31 (168 hours) start_forecast = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-24 00:00:00') eval_end = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-31 23:00:00') for feature, forecast_df in input_predictions.items(): # Restrict forecasted values to where actual data exists valid_idx = forecast_df.index.intersection(df.index) if len(valid_idx) == 0: print(f"⚠️ Skipping {feature}: no overlapping timestamps between predictions and actual data") continue pred = forecast_df.loc[valid_idx, feature] actual = df.loc[valid_idx, feature] if pred.empty or actual.empty: print(f"⚠️ Skipping {feature}: prediction or actual values are empty after filtering") continue mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, pred) rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, pred)) print(f'{feature} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}') plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3)) plt.plot(actual.index, actual, label='Actual') plt.plot(pred.index, pred, label='Predicted') plt.title(f"{feature} Forecast Evaluation") plt.legend() plt.grid(True) plt.show()

You said:
I als want the prediction for these features: 'solar_load_ratio', 'wind_load_ratio'
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — since solar_load_ratio and wind_load_ratio are derived features, we can compute them directly from the forecasted values:

✅ Strategy:

Once you've forecasted:

  • DE_solar_generation_actual

  • DE_wind_generation_actual

  • DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency

You can add this code at the end of the notebook (just before saving to CSV):

python
# ⛏️ Compute derived ratio features
combined['solar_load_ratio'] = (
    combined['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / combined['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
)
combined['wind_load_ratio'] = (
    combined['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / combined['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
)

# 📊 Visualize
for ratio_feature in ['solar_load_ratio', 'wind_load_ratio']:
    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(combined.index, combined[ratio_feature], label='Forecasted Ratio')
    plt.title(f"{ratio_feature} — Forecast (Dec 25–31, 2019)")
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

Let me know if you'd like me to regenerate the full notebook with this built-in, or if you're good to add it manually 👍

You said:
Can I compute the ratio and then forecast it as its own feature?
ChatGPT said:

Yes, you absolutely can do that — and it’s a valid modeling strategy! In fact, treating solar_load_ratio and wind_load_ratio as standalone time series lets you:

✅ Pros of Forecasting the Ratios Directly:

  • Avoid propagation of error from two separate forecasts (solar / load)

  • Capture their own seasonal and trend behavior

  • Keep the model structure consistent for all forecasted inputs

🧠 Strategy Options

You now have two options:

🔁 Option A: Derive the ratios after forecasting solar, wind, and load

  • More interpretable

  • Requires accurate forecasts for both numerator and denominator

🔮 Option B: Forecast the ratios directly

  • Treated as separate target features

  • Could be more stable for the model (especially if load is noisy)

✅ Implementation Plan (Option B):

  1. Add these to your features_to_forecast list:

python
features_to_forecast = [
    'DE_solar_generation_actual',
    'DE_wind_generation_actual',
    'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency',
    ...
    'solar_load_ratio',
    'wind_load_ratio'
]

  1. Pre-compute the ratios before the loop:

python
df['solar_load_ratio'] = df['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
df['wind_load_ratio'] = df['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']

  1. Let the loop forecast them like any other feature (same lags, calendar, etc.)

Would you like me to regenerate the notebook with this approach?
Or send you just the updated code to paste in?

You said:
Okay I got the results, now I want to evaluate them against the values in the "merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv" file. be carefule that the file does not contain the ratios. just give me a code block to add to the end of the notebook. I want graphs and errors
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — since you now have the forecasted features with ratios, and you want to compare them to the actual values from merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv, here’s a clean evaluation block you can paste at the end of your notebook:

✅ 🔍 Paste this at the end of the notebook:

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error

# 📥 Load actual data again (full range)
df_actual = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df_actual.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)
df_actual = df_actual.sort_index()

# 📆 Evaluation window
eval_start = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-25 00:00:00')
eval_end = pd.Timestamp('2019-12-31 23:00:00')

# 📤 Forecasted data
df_forecast = combined.copy()
df_forecast = df_forecast.loc[eval_start:eval_end]

# 📥 Actual values for matching columns only
columns_to_evaluate = [col for col in df_forecast.columns if col in df_actual.columns]
# For the ratios, we compute them directly from actuals
df_actual['solar_load_ratio'] = df_actual['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / df_actual['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
df_actual['wind_load_ratio'] = df_actual['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / df_actual['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']

# 🔁 Add ratios to columns to evaluate
columns_to_evaluate += ['solar_load_ratio', 'wind_load_ratio']

print("📊 Feature Forecast Evaluation for Dec 25–31, 2019\n")

for col in columns_to_evaluate:
    if col not in df_forecast.columns or col not in df_actual.columns:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: Not found in both actual and forecasted data")
        continue

    y_true = df_actual.loc[eval_start:eval_end, col]
    y_pred = df_forecast[col]

    mae = mean_absolute_error(y_true, y_pred)
    rmse = mean_squared_error(y_true, y_pred, squared=False)

    print(f"{col} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(y_true.index, y_true, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(y_pred.index, y_pred, label='Forecasted')
    plt.title(f"{col} — Forecast vs Actual")
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

🔎 What it does:

  • Loads the original file again (merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv)

  • Computes the actual solar/wind ratios

  • Compares the forecasted features to real ones

  • Prints MAE, RMSE for each

  • Plots each feature on a shared time axis

Let me know how your results look and if you want to prioritize improving any particular forecast!

ChatGPT said:

✅ That error is crystal clear:

“Found input variables with inconsistent numbers of samples: [121, 168]”

It means one of your dataframes (likely df_actual) has fewer timestamps than your forecasted data (df_forecast) for the range 2019-12-25 → 2019-12-31.

🧼 Fix: Align timestamps before computing metrics

We’ll do this by intersecting the index to make sure y_true and y_pred have the same datetime entries.

✅ Replace this block:

python
y_true = df_actual.loc[eval_start:eval_end, col]
y_pred = df_forecast[col]

🔁 With this:

python
# Align actual and predicted on common datetime index
valid_idx = df_forecast.index.intersection(df_actual.index)
y_true = df_actual.loc[valid_idx, col]
y_pred = df_forecast.loc[valid_idx, col]

🧪 Final code block inside your loop:

python
for col in columns_to_evaluate:
    if col not in df_forecast.columns or col not in df_actual.columns:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: Not found in both actual and forecasted data")
        continue

    valid_idx = df_forecast.index.intersection(df_actual.index)
    y_true = df_actual.loc[valid_idx, col]
    y_pred = df_forecast.loc[valid_idx, col]

    if y_true.empty or y_pred.empty:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: no data to compare")
        continue

    mae = mean_absolute_error(y_true, y_pred)
    rmse = mean_squared_error(y_true, y_pred, squared=False)

    print(f"{col} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(y_true.index, y_true, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(y_pred.index, y_pred, label='Forecasted')
    plt.title(f"{col} — Forecast vs Actual")
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

This will cleanly evaluate only where both actual and predicted data exist.

Let me know how it goes!

  • Skips features if any data is missing (instead of crashing)

  • Calculates MAE and RMSE

View as a scrollable element or open in a text editor. Adjust cell output settings...
ChatGPT said:

Ah yes — this error is because your version of scikit-learn is older and doesn’t support the squared=False argument in mean_squared_error.

✅ Quick Fix:

Just manually take the square root of the MSE to compute the RMSE:

🔁 Replace this line:

python
rmse = mean_squared_error(y_true, y_pred, squared=False)

✅ With:

python
rmse = mean_squared_error(y_true, y_pred) ** 0.5

That will work exactly the same way and give you the RMSE, without requiring the squared=False flag.

Let me know if the plots and metrics are working now — and we’ll be ready to use these for final price forecasting!

You said:
The results weren't the best, any suggestions what we can do to improve?
ChatGPT said:

Totally fair — and thanks for bringing it up. Forecasting features accurately is tough, but there are definitely ways we can make meaningful improvements.

Here’s a breakdown of what you can try next, depending on how deep you want to go:

🔧 1. Improve the input features for forecasting each variable

Right now you’re only using:

  • Lag 1h, 24h, 168h

  • Calendar features: hour, dayofweek, month

✅ Suggestions:

  • Add rolling means (e.g., 6h, 24h) to smooth noise
    → data['roll_6h'] = data[feature].rolling(6).mean()

  • Add previous errors/residuals if applicable

  • Add exogenous signals (like irradiance for solar, wind patterns for wind — if available)

🧠 2. Try model stacking or ensembles

Instead of just XGBoost for every feature, you could try:

  • Compare with LightGBM, RandomForest, or even simple linear regression for some smooth features

  • Ensemble models: average predictions from multiple regressors

🌀 3. Use multi-output or sequence models

Instead of forecasting one hour at a time recursively, try:

  • Forecasting a full week in one go using models like:

    • MultiOutputRegressor(XGBoost())

    • LSTM (if you’re willing to go deep learning)

    • Seq2Seq with attention if you’re adventurous

📦 4. Add uncertainty awareness

Sometimes performance looks worse than it is because:

  • There’s seasonal variability, or

  • Some days are much harder to predict than others

Try:

  • Evaluating per day and aggregating results

  • Including confidence intervals in your forecast plots

✅ 5. Focus your effort on the most impactful features

From your earlier tests:

  • Did you find which features had the highest prediction error?

  • Are there features that are less critical for energy price (e.g., diffuse radiation)?

⚠️ You might get more mileage from improving a few key ones (e.g. load, solar, wind) and dropping others.

Would you like me to:

  • Generate a notebook to test rolling averages in the feature forecast loop?

  • Show side-by-side comparison between XGBoost vs RandomForest?

  • Help you redesign to predict the whole week at once instead of recursively?

Let me know what direction you'd like to try!

You said:
Isn't predicting the whole week computationally expensive?
ChatGPT said:

Great question — and the answer is: not necessarily, especially for the kinds of models you’re using like XGBoost.

Let me break it down for you:

🧠 What does "predicting the whole week" mean?

Right now you're likely doing something like:

python
for i in range(168):  # for each hour
    predict t+1 using features at t, t–1, t–24...
    append that prediction
    move to next hour using new prediction

This is recursive, and it’s:

  • Sensitive to errors that accumulate at every step 😬

  • Slower due to multiple rounds of prediction

  • Difficult to parallelize

✅ Predicting the whole week at once:

This means:

  • You prepare one input with all lagged/context features

  • Your model outputs all 168 hours in one shot as a vector

You can do this with:

python
from sklearn.multioutput import MultiOutputRegressor
model = MultiOutputRegressor(XGBRegressor())

It’s:

  • Only marginally more expensive than a single-output model

  • Often more stable because it learns relationships between future points (e.g., if Monday is sunny, Tuesday probably is too)

💡 Trade-offs:

ApproachProsCons
Recursive (hour-by-hour)Lightweight model, easy to debugError accumulates, slower due to loop
Full multi-step outputMore stable predictions, fewer loopsNeeds more RAM/VRAM, slightly more training time

🔍 Reality Check:

You're using 168 outputs per feature → even in a worst case, a modern laptop (or 10-year-old i7 + 16GB RAM like yours) can easily handle this in seconds to minutes with XGBoost.

💡 If you can run recursive forecasting for 168 steps, you can run this.

Would you like a notebook that does:

  • Multi-output XGBoost forecasting for one or all features?

  • Comparison between recursive vs multi-output on the same target?

Let me know how far you want to push!

You said:
Multi-output XGBoost forecasting for all features
ChatGPT said:

✅ Done!

📘 Here's your notebook: 10d_multioutput_forecast_all_features_last_week_2019.ipynb

It will:

  • Use MultiOutputRegressor(XGBRegressor) for each feature

  • Predict all 168 hours (Dec 25–31, 2019) in a single shot

  • Save to: data/processed/multioutput_forecast_all_features_last_week_2019.csv

  • Show forecast plots for all 10 features (including ratios)

Let me know when you're ready to plug these into your final energy price prediction! ​​

You said:
It's been 15 mins for only the first feature
ChatGPT said:

Yeah — 15 minutes sounds longer than expected even for your system. That means we can likely optimize this in a few ways without sacrificing much accuracy. Here’s how to fix it:

🚦 Why is it slow?

The bottleneck is likely from:

  • XGBRegressor(n_estimators=100) being trained 168 times (one per output)

  • Looping over every hour from 2015 to end of 2019

  • Large input size (168 lags) + large output (168 steps)

⚡ Speed-Up Options:

✅ 1. Reduce training size

Use a subset of the data like the last 1 or 2 years:

python
series = series[series.index >= '2018-01-01']

✅ 2. Downsample the time steps

If the pattern is slow-changing (like temperature or oil price), sample every 2 hours:

python
series = series.resample('2H').mean().dropna()
forecast_horizon = 84  # Half the points if every 2 hours

✅ 3. Use fewer estimators (faster training)

python
model = MultiOutputRegressor(XGBRegressor(n_estimators=20))

It will still work surprisingly well for stable features like temperature or irradiance.

✅ 4. Try n_jobs=-1 to use all CPU cores

python
model = MultiOutputRegressor(XGBRegressor(n_estimators=50, n_jobs=-1))

🔁 Want me to regenerate a faster version of the notebook?

I can update it with:

  • Last 2 years only

  • n_estimators=20

  • n_jobs=-1

  • Optional: hourly or 2-hour downsampling

Let me know which of those tweaks you'd like!

You said:
Before that, in notebook 03 we already modeled the energy price assuming we have realtime data. can you write a code block to add to that notebook to know what are the most prominent features and what I can drop?
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely — if you're working in Notebook 03 where you used something like XGBRegressor or LightGBM, you can extract feature importance to see which features are contributing the most to price prediction.

✅ Drop-in Code Block for Feature Importance

Just add this after model training in your Notebook 03:

python
importances = model.feature_importances_
feature_names = X.columns  # assuming you trained on X and y

# Create DataFrame for easier inspection
importance_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Feature': feature_names,
    'Importance': importances
}).sort_values(by='Importance', ascending=False)

# Display top features
print("📊 Top Features by Importance:")
display(importance_df)

# Plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.barh(importance_df['Feature'], importance_df['Importance'])
plt.gca().invert_yaxis()
plt.title("Feature Importance in Energy Price Prediction")
plt.xlabel("Importance")
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

🧠 What You’ll Learn:

  • Top predictors (e.g., price_lag_1h, solar_load_ratio, load, etc.)

  • Redundant or low-impact features you can likely drop (e.g., one of the radiation values, or maybe gas vs oil)

Would you also like a version using SHAP values for deeper interpretability? Or is this quick insight good for now?

# Extract feature importance after training the model
importances = model.feature_importances_

feature_names = features  # this is your list of selected input features

# Wrap into DataFrame

    'Feature': feature_names,
    'Importance': importances
}).sort_values(by='Importance', ascending=False)

plt.gca().invert_yaxis()
plt.title("Feature Importance in Energy Price Prediction")

plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

y = df_model['Price (EUR/MWhe)']

If that’s different, let me know and I’ll tweak it.
Once you run this, we can look at what’s worth keeping or dropping!

You said:
What is SHAP
ChatGPT said:

Great question — SHAP is one of the most powerful tools for interpreting machine learning models 🔍

🧠 What is SHAP?

SHAP stands for SHapley Additive exPlanations.
It’s a method based on game theory that explains the contribution of each feature to an individual prediction.

🧪 Why is it awesome?

Unlike just feature importance (which shows average influence), SHAP tells you:

What It Tells YouWhy It’s Useful
Which features pushed a prediction up or downHelps explain why a price was high or low
How much each feature contributedShows how much solar, wind, etc. influenced price
Consistent and model-agnosticWorks with XGBoost, LightGBM, neural nets, etc.

📊 SHAP vs Feature Importance:

Feature ImportanceSHAP
📦 Average-basedYesNo (instance-based)
📈 Global insightYesYes
🔍 Local insight❌ (not specific to a row)✅ (explains each prediction)
🧠 Theory-basedNo (heuristic)Yes (based on Shapley values)

✅ Example Visualization:

SHAP gives you things like this:

<img src="https://shap.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_images/shap_summary_plot.png" width="600"/>

  • Each dot = a prediction

  • Color = feature value (red = high, blue = low)

  • Horizontal position = SHAP value (impact on output)

⚙️ Want to try it?

I can generate a code block that uses SHAP on your trained XGBoost model and shows:

  • Global summary (which features matter most)

  • Local explanation (why price spiked at a certain hour)

Would you like to try that on your energy price model?

You said:
Yes please
ChatGPT said:

✅ Done! Here's your SHAP analysis notebook:

📘 03b_price_model_shap_analysis.ipynb

It includes:

  • ✅ Training a model on your existing features

  • 📊 Global feature importance via SHAP

  • 🐝 Beeswarm plot to see how features push predictions up/down

  • 💧 Waterfall plot for a single prediction explanation

Let me know when you run it — we can use the insights to simplify your model or justify why some features matter most! ​​

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for sharing the results — they’re super insightful. Let’s break down what these SHAP plots are telling you:

🧠 TL;DR Summary

✅ Most influential feature: price_lag_1h
✅ Moderately useful: hour, load, wind_load_ratio
⚠️ Very low impact: Gas_Price, DE_temperature, price_roll_24h, price_roll_168h, etc.

🔍 Global Importance (Bar Chart)

This shows average influence of features on model predictions:

FeatureWhat it meansImpact
price_lag_1hPrevious hour's price🔥🔥🔥
hourTime of day🔥
DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparencyReal-time consumption🔥
wind_load_ratio, solar_gen, oil_priceSome minor impact🧊
price_roll_24h, gas_price, tempBasically not useful in this model🧊

🌈 Beeswarm Plot

This shows how high/low feature values push the prediction:

  • Blue = low values, Red = high values

  • For price_lag_1h: high values (red) push price up (as expected)

  • Features like Gas_Price barely affect the prediction

💧 Local Explanation (Waterfall)

You chose a specific prediction and it shows:

  • price_lag_1h had the biggest downward pull on price

  • Minor pushes/pulls from load, wind_load_ratio, etc.

  • Some features had zero contribution (e.g., solar_gen, hour, gas_price)

✅ What You Can Do Next

🔥 Keep These:

  • price_lag_1h, price_lag_24h

  • hour, load, wind_load_ratio

🧹 Drop or Reconsider:

  • Gas_Price, DE_temperature, price_roll_24h, month, dayofweek, etc.

  • These may still be useful if modeled differently (e.g. forecasted long-term), but they don’t help much in a near-term price model.

💡 Suggestions

  1. Slim the feature set in the real-time model for faster training and better generalization.

  2. Use this SHAP analysis in your final report/poster — it strengthens your model justification.

  3. If you want to improve Gas_Price and Temperature utility, they may need to be used in a long-term price model, not short-term.

Would you like me to generate a lean version of your baseline model with only the top SHAP features?

You said:
It's done, now I need a code block to evaluate the results against the actual ones
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — here’s a code block you can drop at the end of your notebook to evaluate the predictions in multioutput_forecast_shap_features_fast.csv against the actual values in merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv.

✅ Evaluation Code Block (with plots and metrics)

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error

# Load actual and predicted
df_actual = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp']).set_index('utc_timestamp')
df_forecast = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/multioutput_forecast_shap_features_fast.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp']).set_index('utc_timestamp')

# Intersect timestamps
common_index = df_actual.index.intersection(df_forecast.index)

# Filter both
df_actual = df_actual.loc[common_index]
df_forecast = df_forecast.loc[common_index]

# Columns to evaluate
columns_to_evaluate = df_forecast.columns

# Evaluate
for col in columns_to_evaluate:
    if col not in df_actual.columns:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: not found in actual data")
        continue

    y_true = df_actual[col]
    y_pred = df_forecast[col]

    if y_true.empty or y_pred.empty:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: no data to compare")
        continue

    mae = mean_absolute_error(y_true, y_pred)
    rmse = mean_squared_error(y_true, y_pred, squared=False)

    print(f"{col} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

    # Plot
    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(y_true.index, y_true, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(y_pred.index, y_pred, label='Predicted')
    plt.title(f"{col} — Forecast vs Actual")
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

Let me know the results! If anything looks off (e.g., negative values, constant curves), we can refine the training logic or add postprocessing.

ChatGPT said:

Ah, that error means the multioutput_forecast_shap_features_fast.csv file doesn’t have a column named "utc_timestamp" — the index was probably saved without explicitly naming it.

Let’s fix that by updating the read logic. Here's the corrected block that sets the index from the CSV without requiring a named datetime column:

✅ Fixed Evaluation Code

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error

# Load actual data
df_actual = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df_actual.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Load forecast data (index column is unnamed)
df_forecast = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/multioutput_forecast_shap_features_fast.csv', index_col=0, parse_dates=True)

# Align on common timestamps
common_index = df_actual.index.intersection(df_forecast.index)
df_actual = df_actual.loc[common_index]
df_forecast = df_forecast.loc[common_index]

# Evaluate forecasts
for col in df_forecast.columns:
    if col not in df_actual.columns:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: not found in actual data")
        continue

    y_true = df_actual[col]
    y_pred = df_forecast[col]

    if y_true.empty or y_pred.empty:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: no data to compare")
        continue

    mae = mean_absolute_error(y_true, y_pred)
    rmse = mean_squared_error(y_true, y_pred, squared=False)

    print(f"{col} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(y_true.index, y_true, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(y_pred.index, y_pred, label='Predicted')
    plt.title(f"{col} — Forecast vs Actual")
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

This version:

  • Reads the forecast file with the first column as the datetime index.

  • Works even if utc_timestamp wasn’t explicitly named.

  • Aligns predictions and actuals for a clean comparison.

Run it and let me know how the results look!

You said:

Raises TypeError 3275 if the passed arguments can not be bound. 3276 """ -> 3277 return self._bind(args, kwargs) File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\inspect.py:3266, in Signature._bind(self, args, kwargs, partial) ... 3267 'got an unexpected keyword argument {arg!r}'.format( 3268 arg=next(iter(kwargs)))) 3270 return self._bound_arguments_cls(self, arguments) TypeError: got an unexpected keyword argument 'squared' Output is truncated. View as a scrollable element or open in a text editor. Adjust cell output settings...
ChatGPT said:

Ah — this error means you're using an older version of scikit-learn that doesn't support the squared=False argument in mean_squared_error.

No problem! Here's the compatible fix:

✅ Updated Evaluation Code for Older scikit-learn Versions

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error
import numpy as np

# Load actual data
df_actual = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df_actual.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Load forecast data
df_forecast = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/multioutput_forecast_shap_features_fast.csv', index_col=0, parse_dates=True)

# Align on common timestamps
common_index = df_actual.index.intersection(df_forecast.index)
df_actual = df_actual.loc[common_index]
df_forecast = df_forecast.loc[common_index]

# Evaluate forecasts
for col in df_forecast.columns:
    if col not in df_actual.columns:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: not found in actual data")
        continue

    y_true = df_actual[col]
    y_pred = df_forecast[col]

    if y_true.empty or y_pred.empty:
        print(f"⚠️ Skipping {col}: no data to compare")
        continue

    mae = mean_absolute_error(y_true, y_pred)
    rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y_true, y_pred))  # manual sqrt

    print(f"{col} → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
    plt.plot(y_true.index, y_true, label='Actual')
    plt.plot(y_pred.index, y_pred, label='Predicted')
    plt.title(f"{col} — Forecast vs Actual")
    plt.legend()
    plt.grid(True)
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

Try this and let me know how your feature forecast quality looks! We can improve specific features next if needed.

You said:
⚠️ Skipping wind_load_ratio: not found in actual data ⚠️ Skipping solar_load_ratio: not found in actual data... We need to compute these at some point in the code
ChatGPT said:

Exactly — since wind_load_ratio and solar_load_ratio are derived features, they don’t exist in your original dataset (merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv). You’ll need to recompute them just like we did in the forecast notebook.

Here’s a quick prepend block to compute them before evaluation:

✅ Add This Just After Loading df_actual

python
# Recompute the ratio features in the actual dataset
df_actual['solar_load_ratio'] = df_actual['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / df_actual['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
df_actual['wind_load_ratio'] = df_actual['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / df_actual['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']

This will:

  • Add the two ratio features to the actual DataFrame.

  • Let the evaluation code compare them against your forecasted values.

Drop this in and re-run — you should now get MAE/RMSE and plots for all SHAP-based features ✅

You said:
The results were not amazing but lets just move on. Use these values to calculate the energy prices based on the xgboost model used earlier. just write me code block
ChatGPT said:

Understood — let’s move forward.

Here’s a code block that:

  1. Loads the forecasted SHAP features for the first week of 2020.

  2. Reconstructs all required input features (lags, calendar info, ratios).

  3. Applies your previously trained XGBoost model to predict energy prices for that week.

⚡ Code to Predict Energy Prices for Jan 1–7, 2020 Using Forecasted Inputs

python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from xgboost import XGBRegressor
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load forecasted features
df_inputs = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/multioutput_forecast_shap_features_fast.csv', index_col=0, parse_dates=True)

# Recreate any missing features
df_inputs['price_lag_1h'] = np.nan  # Placeholder, no previous price at t=0
df_inputs['price_lag_24h'] = np.nan
df_inputs['price_lag_168h'] = np.nan

# Create calendar features
df_inputs['hour'] = df_inputs.index.hour
df_inputs['dayofweek'] = df_inputs.index.dayofweek
df_inputs['month'] = df_inputs.index.month

# Final feature set (must match what model was trained on)
features = [
    'price_lag_1h', 'price_lag_24h', 'price_lag_168h',
    'hour', 'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency',
    'wind_load_ratio', 'solar_load_ratio'
]

# Fill lagged prices with actual values from 2019 (optional — if available)
# Or just set to 0 or reasonable baseline
df_inputs[['price_lag_1h', 'price_lag_24h', 'price_lag_168h']] = 0

# Load or reuse model
model = XGBRegressor(n_estimators=100)
df_all = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df_all.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)
df_all['price_lag_1h'] = df_all['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(1)
df_all['price_lag_24h'] = df_all['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24)
df_all['price_lag_168h'] = df_all['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(168)
df_all['hour'] = df_all.index.hour
df_all['dayofweek'] = df_all.index.dayofweek
df_all['month'] = df_all.index.month
df_all['solar_load_ratio'] = df_all['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / df_all['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
df_all['wind_load_ratio'] = df_all['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / df_all['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']

# Train model using original data
df_train = df_all[features + ['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].dropna()
X_train = df_train[features]
y_train = df_train['Price (EUR/MWhe)']
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Predict on new inputs
y_pred = model.predict(df_inputs[features])

# Plot
plt.figure(figsize=(14, 4))
plt.plot(df_inputs.index, y_pred, label='Predicted Price')
plt.title("⚡ Energy Price Forecast (Using Forecasted SHAP Features)")
plt.ylabel("Price (EUR/MWhe)")
plt.xlabel("Datetime")
plt.grid(True)
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# Save if needed
df_price_forecast = pd.DataFrame({'Price (EUR/MWhe)': y_pred}, index=df_inputs.index)
df_price_forecast.to_csv('../data/processed/final_energy_price_forecast_2020_week1.csv')
print("✅ Forecasted energy prices saved.")

Let me know if you want to compare these to the actuals visually or compute metrics!

You said:
I want to plot against actual prices and evaluate
ChatGPT said:

Great — here’s a follow-up code block that compares your predicted energy prices against the actual prices from the same week (Jan 1–7, 2020):

📈 Plot + Evaluation Code for Forecasted vs. Actual Energy Prices

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error

# Load actual prices
df_actual = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df_actual.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Filter actual prices for Jan 1–7, 2020
actual_prices = df_actual['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].loc['2020-01-01':'2020-01-07']

# Load forecasted prices
df_forecast = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/final_energy_price_forecast_2020_week1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df_forecast.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)
predicted_prices = df_forecast['Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# Align
common_index = actual_prices.index.intersection(predicted_prices.index)
actual = actual_prices.loc[common_index]
predicted = predicted_prices.loc[common_index]

# Evaluate
mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, predicted)
rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, predicted))
print(f"🔍 Final Evaluation → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

# Plot
plt.figure(figsize=(14, 4))
plt.plot(actual.index, actual, label='Actual Price')
plt.plot(predicted.index, predicted, label='Predicted Price')
plt.title("🔍 Energy Price Forecast vs Actual (Jan 1–7, 2020)")
plt.ylabel("Price (EUR/MWhe)")
plt.xlabel("Datetime")
plt.grid(True)
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

This will give you:

  • 📊 MAE and RMSE scores

  • 🖼️ Side-by-side plot of actual vs predicted prices

Let me know what the final accuracy looks like — we can document or analyze it further if needed!

You said:
This code evaluates against the first week of 2020 while the values we got were for the last week of 2019
ChatGPT said:

Ah yes — you're absolutely right!

Your forecasted features were generated for the last week of 2019 (Dec 25–31), and you used those to predict the first week of 2020 (Jan 1–7). So the correct evaluation window for actual prices should be Jan 1–7, 2020 — that part is still correct.

But — if your final price forecast was actually produced for Dec 25–31, 2019, then yes, we need to compare against that week instead.

✅ So here's the adjusted version for:

⚡ Forecasted Prices from Dec 25–31, 2019

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error

# Load actual prices
df_actual = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df_actual.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Adjusted evaluation window to match forecast horizon
actual_prices = df_actual['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].loc['2019-12-25':'2019-12-31']

# Load forecasted prices
df_forecast = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/final_energy_price_forecast_2020_week1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
df_forecast.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)
predicted_prices = df_forecast['Price (EUR/MWhe)']

# Align both
common_index = actual_prices.index.intersection(predicted_prices.index)
actual = actual_prices.loc[common_index]
predicted = predicted_prices.loc[common_index]

# Evaluate
mae = mean_absolute_error(actual, predicted)
rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(actual, predicted))
print(f"📉 Final Evaluation (Dec 25–31) → MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

# Plot
plt.figure(figsize=(14, 4))
plt.plot(actual.index, actual, label='Actual Price')
plt.plot(predicted.index, predicted, label='Predicted Price')
plt.title("🔍 Energy Price Forecast vs Actual (Dec 25–31, 2019)")
plt.ylabel("Price (EUR/MWhe)")
plt.xlabel("Datetime")
plt.grid(True)
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

Let me know which week you actually predicted for — and I’ll make sure the code matches exactly. If you used forecasted features for Dec 25–31 to predict Jan 1–7, then the previous version was correct!
