ChatGPT said:

Thanks! This error comes from older versions of scikit-learn, where mean_squared_error does not support the squared=False argument.

To fix it for your setup, just remove the squared=False argument and apply the square root manually.

✅ Fixed Step 4 (Model Training & Evaluation)

python
from xgboost import XGBRegressor
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Train the model
model = XGBRegressor(n_estimators=100, random_state=42)
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Predict
y_pred = model.predict(X_test)

# Evaluate
mae = mean_absolute_error(y_test, y_pred)
rmse = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred))  # no squared=False

print(f"MAE: {mae:.2f}, RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")

# Plot actual vs predicted
plt.figure(figsize=(15, 4))
plt.plot(y_test.index, y_test, label='Actual')
plt.plot(y_test.index, y_pred, label='Predicted')
plt.legend()
plt.title('Energy Price Forecast — Multimodal Model (Hourly)')
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

Would you like me to update the notebook in the canvas with all these fixes as well?

You said:
So the base model performed better than the multi-modal
ChatGPT said:

Yes, based on your MAE and RMSE values, it seems the base model (using only structured energy data and engineered features) performed better than the multimodal model that included news sentiment.

This can happen for a few reasons:

  1. Noise in sentiment data — news headlines can be noisy, general, or misaligned with price-driving events.

  2. Low correlation — even categories that seemed relevant (like “Middle East” or “Oil Markets”) showed only weak correlations with actual prices.

  3. Sparsity — there might not be enough relevant news at the right times to consistently boost prediction accuracy.

  4. Feature scaling issues — combining differently scaled features without normalization can hurt models like XGBoost if not handled well.

That said, this finding still supports your case: multimodal models aren’t always better, especially when unstructured data doesn't provide a strong signal.

Would you like to run an ablation test to measure how much each feature group contributes to performance? Or would you rather focus on improving sentiment representation (e.g., topic modeling or classification)?

You said:
how about we lag the news one day behind for it to make more sense
ChatGPT said:

That’s a very smart idea — lagging the news sentiment by 1 day makes conceptual sense because:

  • Cause → effect: News breaks first, market reacts later.

  • It gives the model a more realistic causal relationship (you’d know the sentiment at time t when predicting the price at t+1 or later).

  • It avoids data leakage — where the model might “peek into the future” if news is reported after price changes.

✅ Here’s how to implement that:

You can shift the sentiment dataframe by 1 day before merging:

python
# Step 1: Load sentiment data
sentiment_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/filtered_energy_news_with_sentiment.csv', parse_dates=['date'])
sentiment_df = sentiment_df.rename(columns={'date': 'utc_timestamp'})
sentiment_df.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Shift sentiment one day forward so the value at time t reflects sentiment at t-1 day
sentiment_df = sentiment_df.shift(24, freq='H')  # assumes hourly index

# Resample to hourly
sentiment_hourly = sentiment_df.resample('H').mean().ffill()

Then continue with the merge as before. This way, the model will only see sentiment that was published before the target price.

Would you like me to regenerate the notebook with this shift included and clean up the rest too?

You said:
does this code go in step 1?
ChatGPT said:

Yes — this code replaces the sentiment part of Step 1. Here's the full, clean block for Step 1 with the 1-day lag added in:

✅ Step 1: Load and Shift Sentiment Data

python
import pandas as pd

# Load energy data
energy_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
energy_df.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Load sentiment data
sentiment_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/filtered_energy_news_with_sentiment.csv', parse_dates=['date'])
sentiment_df = sentiment_df.rename(columns={'date': 'utc_timestamp'})
sentiment_df.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Shift sentiment by 1 day to avoid future leakage
sentiment_df = sentiment_df.shift(24, freq='H')  # 24 hours

# Resample to hourly and forward-fill missing
sentiment_hourly = sentiment_df.resample('H').mean().ffill()

Once this is in place, you can continue with Step 2: Merge Datasets as before.

Let me know if you'd like the rest of the notebook updated to follow this setup!

You said:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------- TypeError Traceback (most recent call last) File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\groupby\groupby.py:1942, in GroupBy._agg_py_fallback(self, how, values, ndim, alt) 1941 try: -> 1942 res_values = self._grouper.agg_series(ser, alt, preserve_dtype=True) 1943 except Exception as err: File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\groupby\ops.py:864, in BaseGrouper.agg_series(self, obj, func, preserve_dtype) 862 preserve_dtype = True --> 864 result = self._aggregate_series_pure_python(obj, func) 866 npvalues = lib.maybe_convert_objects(result, try_float=False) File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\groupby\ops.py:885, in BaseGrouper._aggregate_series_pure_python(self, obj, func) 884 for i, group in enumerate(splitter): --> 885 res = func(group) 886 res = extract_result(res) File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\groupby\groupby.py:2454, in GroupBy.mean.<locals>.<lambda>(x) 2451 else: 2452 result = self._cython_agg_general( 2453 "mean", -> 2454 alt=lambda x: Series(x, copy=False).mean(numeric_only=numeric_only), 2455 numeric_only=numeric_only, 2456 ) 2457 return result.__finalize__(self.obj, method="groupby") ... -> 1946 raise type(err)(msg) from err 1948 if ser.dtype == object: 1949 res_values = res_values.astype(object, copy=False) TypeError: agg function failed [how->mean,dtype->object] Output is truncated. View as a scrollable element or open in a text editor. Adjust cell output settings...
ChatGPT said:

This error is happening because sentiment_df contains non-numeric columns, and .resample('H').mean() is trying to average them — which fails.

To fix it, we should only resample numeric columns (like avg_score, pos_ratio). Here’s the corrected Step 1 code block with the 1-day lag and safe resampling:

✅ Fixed Step 1 (with 1-day shift and clean resampling)

python
import pandas as pd

# Load energy data
energy_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
energy_df.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Load sentiment data
sentiment_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/filtered_energy_news_with_sentiment.csv', parse_dates=['date'])
sentiment_df = sentiment_df.rename(columns={'date': 'utc_timestamp'})
sentiment_df.set_index('utc_timestamp', inplace=True)

# Shift sentiment by 1 day to avoid future leakage
sentiment_df = sentiment_df.shift(freq='1D')

# Select only numeric sentiment columns
sentiment_numeric = sentiment_df[['avg_score', 'pos_ratio']]

# Resample to hourly and forward-fill
sentiment_hourly = sentiment_numeric.resample('H').mean().ffill()

Let me know if you want me to apply this clean version to your full notebook again.

You said:
Lets start over. Write me a code block that reads from final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv, and computes the avg_score and pos ratio per day for each of the categories
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely! Here's a clean code block that:

  1. Reads the final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv file.

  2. Converts the date column to datetime (if not already).

  3. Groups by both date and category.

  4. Computes the daily average sentiment score and positive ratio per category.

✅ Compute Daily avg_score and pos_ratio per Category

python
import pandas as pd

# Load filtered news with sentiment
news_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv', parse_dates=['date'])

# Ensure 'date' is datetime (truncate to date only if time is included)
news_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(news_df['date']).dt.floor('D')

# Group by date and category, then compute mean metrics
daily_sentiment = news_df.groupby(['date', 'category'])[['avg_score', 'pos_ratio']].mean().reset_index()

# Display preview
print(daily_sentiment.head())

Let me know if you'd like to pivot this data into a wide format for modeling, or aggregate across categories instead.

You said:
Lets start over. Write me a code block that reads from final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv, and computes the avg_score and pos ratio per day for each of the categories
ChatGPT said:

Certainly! Here's a fresh code block that starts from scratch, reads your final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv, and computes the daily average sentiment score (avg_score) and positive sentiment ratio (pos_ratio) for each category:

✅ Daily Sentiment Aggregation per Category

python
import pandas as pd

# Load the sentiment-annotated and filtered news dataset
news_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv', parse_dates=['date'])

# Ensure the 'date' column is datetime and truncate to just date (no time)
news_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(news_df['date']).dt.date

# Group by date and category, and compute average sentiment and positive ratio
daily_category_sentiment = (
    news_df
    .groupby(['date', 'category'])[['avg_score', 'pos_ratio']]
    .mean()
    .reset_index()
)

# Preview
print(daily_category_sentiment.head())

This gives you one row per (date, category) combination with avg_score and pos_ratio. You can later pivot it into a format where each category becomes a separate column if needed for modeling.

ChatGPT said:

Thanks! That error means the columns avg_score and pos_ratio don’t exist in your file (yet). Let's inspect the actual column names and then compute those columns before doing the daily aggregation.

Here's the fixed, complete block:

✅ Load, Inspect, Compute Sentiment Metrics by Day and Category

python
import pandas as pd

# Load dataset
news_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv', parse_dates=['date'])

# Check available columns
print("Columns:", news_df.columns.tolist())

# Make sure 'score' exists (the sentiment score from BERT)
if 'score' not in news_df.columns:
    raise ValueError("Expected a 'score' column for sentiment value!")

# Create binary sentiment (positive if score > 0)
news_df['is_positive'] = news_df['score'] > 0

# Truncate datetime to date
news_df['date'] = news_df['date'].dt.date

# Group by date and category
daily_category_sentiment = (
    news_df.groupby(['date', 'category'])
    .agg(
        avg_score=('score', 'mean'),
        pos_ratio=('is_positive', 'mean'),
        sample_size=('score', 'count')
    )
    .reset_index()
)

# Preview result
print(daily_category_sentiment.head())

Let me know if you'd like to:

  • Filter categories

  • Merge with price data

You said:
Yes I know they don't exist I need to compute them like we did notebook 09d
ChatGPT said:

Perfect! Let's recreate what we did in Notebook 09d by computing:

  • avg_score: average sentiment score per group

  • pos_ratio: ratio of positive headlines (score > 0)

Here’s a clean code block that loads final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv and computes the average score and positive ratio per day per category, just like in 09d:

📊 Compute avg_score and pos_ratio Per Day and Category

python
import pandas as pd

# Load the sentiment-labeled news dataset
news_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv', parse_dates=['date'])

# Drop missing scores if any
news_df = news_df.dropna(subset=['score'])

# Add a binary column for positive sentiment
news_df['is_positive'] = news_df['score'] > 0

# Truncate datetime to date
news_df['date'] = news_df['date'].dt.date

# Group by date and category
daily_category_sentiment = (
    news_df.groupby(['date', 'category'])
    .agg(
        avg_score=('score', 'mean'),
        pos_ratio=('is_positive', 'mean'),
        sample_size=('score', 'count')
    )
    .reset_index()
)

# Preview
print(daily_category_sentiment.head())

✅ This mirrors the 09d logic. Let me know if you want this pivoted (e.g., categories as columns), filtered, merged with price, or resampled to hourly.

You said:
yes I want the categories as columns
ChatGPT said:

Great! To pivot the table so each category becomes a column, you'll want to reshape the daily_category_sentiment DataFrame. Here's a block that gives you two pivoted tables:

  • One for avg_score

  • One for pos_ratio

🔁 Pivot: Categories as Columns

python
# Pivot to have one column per category for avg_score
pivot_avg_score = daily_category_sentiment.pivot(index='date', columns='category', values='avg_score')

# Pivot for pos_ratio
pivot_pos_ratio = daily_category_sentiment.pivot(index='date', columns='category', values='pos_ratio')

# Optional: merge both into a single DataFrame with multi-level columns
pivot_combined = pd.concat(
    {'avg_score': pivot_avg_score, 'pos_ratio': pivot_pos_ratio}, 
    axis=1
)

# Preview
pivot_combined.head()

  • Restrict to specific categories,

  • Join with energy price data.

You said:
take this code but adjust it so that it filters by category: # Step 3: Convert to daily average sentiment daily_sentiment = sentiment_df.groupby(sentiment_df['date'].dt.date).agg( avg_score=('sentiment_score', 'mean'), pos_ratio=('sentiment', lambda x: (x == 'POSITIVE').mean()), count=('sentiment', 'count') ).rename_axis('date').reset_index() daily_sentiment['date'] = pd.to_datetime(daily_sentiment['date']) daily_sentiment.set_index('date', inplace=True) daily_sentiment.tail()
ChatGPT said:

Sure! Here's a version of your code that computes the daily average sentiment per category, including:

  • avg_score per category per day

  • pos_ratio (proportion of POSITIVE headlines)

  • count (number of headlines)

Each (day, category) is a row:

python
# Step 3: Daily average sentiment per category
sentiment_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['date']).dt.date

daily_sentiment_by_category = (
    sentiment_df
    .groupby(['date', 'category'])
    .agg(
        avg_score=('sentiment_score', 'mean'),
        pos_ratio=('sentiment', lambda x: (x == 'POSITIVE').mean()),
        count=('sentiment', 'count')
    )
    .reset_index()
)

# Convert 'date' to datetime and set as index
daily_sentiment_by_category['date'] = pd.to_datetime(daily_sentiment_by_category['date'])
daily_sentiment_by_category.set_index('date', inplace=True)

# Preview
daily_sentiment_by_category.tail()

Let me know if you want to pivot this by category (so each category becomes a column), or join with the energy price dataset!

You said:
okay now give me a code tha turns the categories into columns
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely! To pivot the daily_sentiment_by_category dataframe so that each category becomes its own column (with values like avg_score or pos_ratio), you can use the following code:

python
# Pivot to wide format: one column per category per metric
pivoted_sentiment = daily_sentiment_by_category.pivot_table(
    index=daily_sentiment_by_category.index,  # date is already the index
    columns='category',
    values=['avg_score', 'pos_ratio']
)

# Flatten the multi-level column names
pivoted_sentiment.columns = [f'{metric}_{cat}' for metric, cat in pivoted_sentiment.columns]
pivoted_sentiment = pivoted_sentiment.sort_index()

# Preview result
pivoted_sentiment.tail()

This will create columns like avg_score_Markets, pos_ratio_Politics, etc., one for each category and metric.

Let me know if you want to filter to specific categories or merge this into your energy dataset!

ChatGPT said:

You're absolutely right to question that — you included 16 categories in your top_categories list, but only 6 appear in the filtered output. This usually happens when:

  1. The category names in your list don't exactly match what's in the dataset (e.g., case sensitivity, extra spaces).

  2. Some categories may not exist at all in the current CSV (filtered_energy_news_with_sentiment.csv).

✅ Here's how to troubleshoot it:

Run the following snippet before filtering to see the unique categories that actually exist in your dataset:

python
# Show unique categories in the current sentiment file
print("📋 Unique categories in sentiment dataset:")
print(sorted(sentiment_df['category'].unique()))

This will help you:

  • Spot mismatches like 'POLITICS' vs 'Politics'

  • Detect missing entries (e.g., 'Europe', 'Markets', 'Middle East')

✅ Suggested Fix

Once you identify the exact names, revise the list like this:

python
# Adjusted after checking actual category values
top_categories = [
    'POLITICS', 'Politics', 'WORLD NEWS', 'Commentary', 'early lead',
    'THE WORLDPOST', 'World', 'Oil Markets', 'Earnings',
    'Review & Outlook', 'Central Banks', 'IMPACT', 'SCIENCE'
]

⚠️ Some categories like 'Europe', 'Middle East', 'Markets' may not exist in this dataset at all — they might’ve appeared in a different data source or were dropped earlier.

Let me know what you find after printing the unique categories — we can rebuild the top_categories list accordingly!

You said:
📋 Unique categories in sentiment dataset: [' Business', ' Central Banks', ' Commentary', ' Earnings', ' Economic Data', ' Europe', ' Markets', ' Middle East', ' Oil Markets', ' Politics', ' REVIEW & OUTLOOK', ' REVIEW & OUTLOOK ', ' Review & Outlook', ' Review & outlook', ' Science', ' World', ' review & outlook', 'BUSINESS', 'IMPACT', 'POLITICS', 'SCIENCE', 'THE WORLDPOST', 'WORLD NEWS', 'WORLDPOST', 'business', 'capital weather gang', 'early lead', 'opinions', 'politics', 'post politics', 'science', 'world', 'worldviews']
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — this explains it! Many of the categories in your list exist with leading/trailing spaces, inconsistent capitalization, or slightly different spellings (like 'REVIEW & OUTLOOK' vs 'Review & Outlook').

✅ Clean Fix:

Let’s normalize the categories before filtering. This way, we don’t need to chase every variation manually.

python
import pandas as pd

# Load sentiment data
sentiment_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/filtered_energy_news_with_sentiment.csv', parse_dates=['date'])

# Strip whitespace and lowercase all category names for consistency
sentiment_df['category'] = sentiment_df['category'].str.strip().str.lower()

# Define top categories (normalized)
top_categories = [
    'middle east', 'europe', 'world news', 'commentary', 'early lead',
    'politics', 'markets', 'the worldpost', 'review & outlook',
    'world', 'central banks', 'earnings', 'oil markets',
    'impact', 'science'
]

# Filter
filtered_sentiment_df = sentiment_df[sentiment_df['category'].isin(top_categories)]

# Save
filtered_sentiment_df.to_csv('../data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv', index=False)
print('✅ Filtered and saved top-category sentiment data to /data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv')

# Show category counts
print("\nFiltered category distribution:")
print(filtered_sentiment_df['category'].value_counts())

✨ Result:

  • You'll catch all variants like ' Review & Outlook ' and 'REVIEW & OUTLOOK'.

  • You’ll get a more complete set of news for each meaningful category.

  • Your modeling input will be much cleaner 🔍

Let me know if you want to reformat the categories back to proper case later!

You said:
how should I change this code accordingly? import pandas as pd # Load sentiment-annotated news sentiment_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/filtered_energy_news_with_sentiment.csv', parse_dates=['date']) # Define top categories based on prior correlation analysis top_categories = [ 'Middle East', 'Europe', 'WORLD NEWS', 'Commentary', 'early lead', 'POLITICS', 'Politics', 'Markets', 'THE WORLDPOST', 'Review & Outlook', 'World', 'Central Banks', 'Earnings', "Oil Markets", "IMPACT", "SCIENCE" ] # Filter filtered_sentiment_df = sentiment_df[sentiment_df['category'].isin(top_categories)] # Save filtered dataset filtered_sentiment_df.to_csv('../data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv', index=False) print('✅ Filtered and saved top-category sentiment data to /data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv') # Optional: Display counts per category print("\nFiltered category distribution:") print(filtered_sentiment_df['category'].value_counts())
ChatGPT said:

You can modify your code like this to normalize category names before filtering, which ensures that inconsistent capitalization or extra spaces don’t cause you to miss relevant entries:

✅ Updated Version:

python
import pandas as pd

# Load sentiment-annotated news
sentiment_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/filtered_energy_news_with_sentiment.csv', parse_dates=['date'])

# Normalize category column
sentiment_df['category'] = sentiment_df['category'].str.strip().str.lower()

# Define top categories in lowercase (normalized)
top_categories = [
    'middle east', 'europe', 'world news', 'commentary', 'early lead',
    'politics', 'markets', 'the worldpost', 'review & outlook',
    'world', 'central banks', 'earnings', 'oil markets',
    'impact', 'science'
]

# Filter dataset
filtered_sentiment_df = sentiment_df[sentiment_df['category'].isin(top_categories)]

# Save to file
filtered_sentiment_df.to_csv('../data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv', index=False)
print('✅ Filtered and saved top-category sentiment data to /data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv')

# Display counts per category
print("\nFiltered category distribution:")
print(filtered_sentiment_df['category'].value_counts())

This change guarantees you're catching all variants of each category (e.g., ' Review & Outlook', 'REVIEW & OUTLOOK', 'review & outlook', etc.).

Let me know if you'd like to rename them back to their original formatting afterward (e.g., for cleaner visuals or plots).

You said:
can I change this piece of code to include the hour? sentiment_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['date']).dt.date
ChatGPT said:

Yes, you absolutely can! If you want to retain the full datetime including the hour (instead of reducing it to just the date), you should remove the .dt.date part.

✅ Modified Code (to keep the hour):

python
sentiment_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['date'])  # Keep full timestamp with hour

This will preserve the YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format, which is especially useful if you're aligning it with hourly energy price data.

Let me know if you also want to floor it to the nearest hour (e.g., strip minutes and seconds).

You said:
yes floor it to the nearest hour
ChatGPT said:

Great! To floor the datetime to the nearest hour (i.e., strip minutes, seconds, and microseconds), use .dt.floor('H') like this:

✅ Final Code (floored to hour):

python
sentiment_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['date']).dt.floor('H')

This will convert timestamps like:

yaml
2018-06-12 14:37:45 → 2018-06-12 14:00:00

Perfect for aligning with hourly data like energy prices or weather.

Let me know if you’d like to aggregate the sentiment per hour after this.

You said:
What does this mean? C:\Users\iTECH\AppData\Local\Temp\ipykernel_8580\2680835921.py:2: FutureWarning: 'H' is deprecated and will be removed in a future version, please use 'h' instead. sentiment_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['date']).dt.floor('H')
ChatGPT said:

That warning is just letting you know that uppercase 'H' (for "hour") in .dt.floor('H') is deprecated and will be removed in a future version of pandas.

You should switch to using lowercase 'h' instead. ✅

✅ Corrected Version:

python
sentiment_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['date']).dt.floor('h')

It works exactly the same way — just future-proofed.
Let me know if you'd like help aggregating or merging based on this new hourly timestamp!

You said:
Is there a way to see if there are missing values in an hourly time series?
ChatGPT said:

Yes — you can absolutely check for missing timestamps in an hourly time series. Here's a simple and effective way to do it:

✅ Code to Detect Missing Timestamps (Hourly)

python
# Ensure the datetime column is the index
sentiment_df = sentiment_df.set_index('date').sort_index()

# Create a complete range of hourly timestamps
full_range = pd.date_range(start=sentiment_df.index.min(), end=sentiment_df.index.max(), freq='h')

# Find which expected timestamps are missing
missing = full_range.difference(sentiment_df.index)

print(f"⏰ Missing timestamps: {len(missing)}")
if not missing.empty:
    print(missing)
else:
    print("✅ No missing timestamps found.")

This will:

  • Sort and align your time index,

  • Generate the full expected hourly range,

  • Identify gaps in the index,

  • And show you what’s missing.

Let me know if you'd like to fill or interpolate those gaps after detecting them.

You said:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------- KeyError Traceback (most recent call last) ~\AppData\Local\Temp\ipykernel_8580\3081416645.py in ?() 1 # Ensure the datetime column is the index ----> 2 hourly_sentiment = hourly_sentiment.set_index('utc_timestamp').sort_index() 3 4 # Create a complete range of hourly timestamps 5 full_range = pd.date_range(start=hourly_sentiment.index.min(), end=hourly_sentiment.index.max(), freq='h') c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\frame.py in ?(self, keys, drop, append, inplace, verify_integrity) 6118 if not found: 6119 missing.append(col) 6120 6121 if missing: -> 6122 raise KeyError(f"None of {missing} are in the columns") 6123 6124 if inplace: 6125 frame = self KeyError: "None of ['utc_timestamp'] are in the columns"
ChatGPT said:

That error means your DataFrame doesn't have a column named 'utc_timestamp'. Based on your earlier steps, it's likely your datetime column is called 'date', especially after flooring it to the nearest hour.

Here’s the fixed version of the code:

✅ Updated Code for Missing Timestamp Detection (using 'date')

python
# Make sure 'date' is the datetime column and set it as the index
hourly_sentiment = sentiment_df.set_index('date').sort_index()

# Create full hourly range based on the existing data
full_range = pd.date_range(start=hourly_sentiment.index.min(), end=hourly_sentiment.index.max(), freq='h')

# Detect missing hours
missing = full_range.difference(hourly_sentiment.index)

print(f"⏰ Missing timestamps: {len(missing)}")
if not missing.empty:
    print(missing)
else:
    print("✅ No missing timestamps found.")

Let me know if you want to fill those missing timestamps using forward fill (ffill()), zero-fill, or interpolation.

You said:

python
# If 'date' is already the index, skip setting it again
hourly_sentiment = sentiment_df.sort_index()

# Create a full range of expected hourly timestamps
full_range = pd.date_range(start=hourly_sentiment.index.min(), end=hourly_sentiment.index.max(), freq='h')

# Find missing timestamps
missing = full_range.difference(hourly_sentiment.index)

print(f"⏰ Missing timestamps: {len(missing)}")
if not missing.empty:
    print(missing)
else:
    print("✅ No missing timestamps found.")

If you're not sure whether 'date' is already the index, you can confirm it by running:

python
print(hourly_sentiment.index.name)

You said:
I ran this code: from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split # Check which sentiment features were merged successfully sentiment_features = [col for col in merged_df.columns if col in ['avg_score', 'pos_ratio']] base_features = [ 'DE_solar_generation_actual', 'DE_wind_generation_actual', 'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency', 'Gas_Price', 'Oil_Price', 'DE_radiation_direct_horizontal', 'DE_radiation_diffuse_horizontal', 'DE_temperature', 'price_lag_24h', 'price_lag_168h', 'price_roll_24h', 'price_roll_168h', 'hour', 'dayofweek', 'month', 'solar_load_ratio', 'wind_load_ratio' ] features = base_features + sentiment_features # ChatGPT said:

The error you're seeing —

plaintext
AttributeError: 'Index' object has no attribute 'hour'

— means that the index of your DataFrame (merged_df.index) is not a datetime index, which is required for accessing .hour, .dayofweek, and .month.

✅ Fix: Ensure index is datetime

python
merged_df.index = pd.to_datetime(merged_df.index)

✅ Updated Code Snippet:

python
# Make sure the index is datetime
merged_df.index = pd.to_datetime(merged_df.index)

# Calendar and ratio features
merged_df['hour'] = merged_df.index.hour
merged_df['dayofweek'] = merged_df.index.dayofweek
merged_df['month'] = merged_df.index.month
merged_df['solar_load_ratio'] = merged_df['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / merged_df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
merged_df['wind_load_ratio'] = merged_df['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / merged_df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']

merged_df = energy_df.merge(hourly_sentiment, left_index=True, right_index=True, how='left')

python
sentiment_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['date']).dt.floor('h')

hourly_sentiment = (
    sentiment_df
    .groupby('date')
    .agg(
        avg_score=('sentiment_score', 'mean'),
        pos_ratio=('sentiment', lambda x: (x == 'POSITIVE').mean()),
        count=('sentiment', 'count')
    )
)

hourly_sentiment.index.name = 'utc_timestamp'

You said:
I double checked all of the above, still getting the same result
ChatGPT said:

Thanks for double-checking — since you've verified the correct aggregation and still see the wrong columns in the merged DataFrame, there's likely a mismatch in timestamp formats or a merge with the wrong DataFrame version. Let's go through a clean and minimal reproducible fix.

✅ Step-by-step Fix: Clean Merge with Aggregated Sentiment

🔹 1. Ensure Sentiment Is Aggregated Hourly

python
import pandas as pd

# Load sentiment
sentiment_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/final_sentiment_filtered_news.csv', parse_dates=['date'])

# Floor to the nearest hour
sentiment_df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['date']).dt.floor('h')

# Aggregate hourly sentiment
hourly_sentiment = sentiment_df.groupby('date').agg(
    avg_score=('sentiment_score', 'mean'),
    pos_ratio=('sentiment', lambda x: (x == 'POSITIVE').mean()),
    count=('sentiment', 'count')
)

# Rename index for consistency
hourly_sentiment.index.name = 'utc_timestamp'
print("✅ Hourly sentiment prepared:", hourly_sentiment.columns.tolist())

🔹 2. Load and Prepare Energy Data

python
# Load energy data
energy_df = pd.read_csv('../data/processed/merged_energy_data_final_step_1.csv', parse_dates=['utc_timestamp'])
energy_df = energy_df.set_index('utc_timestamp')
print("✅ Energy data prepared:", energy_df.columns.tolist())

🔹 3. Merge (THIS is the important part)

python
# Now merge on matching hourly timestamp index
merged_df = energy_df.merge(hourly_sentiment, left_index=True, right_index=True, how='left')

print("✅ Merged columns:", merged_df.columns.tolist())

This should give you:

css
✅ Merged columns: [..., 'avg_score', 'pos_ratio', 'count']

🔍 If You're Still Seeing headline, category, sentiment, etc.:

You are likely merging with sentiment_df instead of hourly_sentiment at some point. Try searching your code for:

python
.merge(sentiment_df, ...)

and replace it with:

python
.merge(hourly_sentiment, ...)

Want me to generate a minimal clean notebook (or script) that does just this and nothing more?

python
sentiment_hourly = sentiment_hourly.sort_index()

python
print(sentiment_hourly.head())
print(sentiment_hourly.tail())

You said:
This is the feature section of the code: from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split # Check which sentiment features were merged successfully sentiment_features = [col for col in merged_df.columns if col in ['avg_score']] base_features = [ 'DE_solar_generation_actual', 'DE_wind_generation_actual', 'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency', 'Gas_Price', 'Oil_Price', 'DE_radiation_direct_horizontal', 'DE_radiation_diffuse_horizontal', 'DE_temperature', 'price_lag_24h', 'price_lag_168h', 'price_roll_24h', 'price_roll_168h', 'hour', 'dayofweek', 'month', 'solar_load_ratio', 'wind_load_ratio' ] features = base_features + sentiment_features # Add lag and rolling features merged_df['price_lag_1h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(1) merged_df['price_lag_24h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24) merged_df['price_lag_168h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(168) merged_df['price_roll_24h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(24).mean() merged_df['price_roll_168h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(168).mean() # Calendar and ratio features merged_df['hour'] = merged_df.index.hour merged_df['dayofweek'] = merged_df.index.dayofweek merged_df['month'] = merged_df.index.month merged_df['solar_load_ratio'] = merged_df['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / merged_df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency'] merged_df['wind_load_ratio'] = merged_df['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / merged_df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency'] # Final dataframe final_df = merged_df[features + ['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].dropna() # Train-test split X = final_df[features] y = final_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'] X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, shuffle=False) .... I want to change it so that the avg_score is lagged 1 day behind
ChatGPT said:

To lag the avg_score by 1 day (i.e., 24 hours in an hourly time series), you can simply shift it by 24 steps before training. Here's how to update your code:

✅ Updated Feature Engineering Section with Lagged Sentiment

python
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split

# Create a lagged version of avg_score
merged_df['avg_score_lag_24h'] = merged_df['avg_score'].shift(24)

# Update sentiment features
sentiment_features = ['avg_score_lag_24h']

# Define full feature list
base_features = [
    'DE_solar_generation_actual', 'DE_wind_generation_actual', 'DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency',
    'Gas_Price', 'Oil_Price', 'DE_radiation_direct_horizontal', 'DE_radiation_diffuse_horizontal',
    'DE_temperature',
    'price_lag_24h', 'price_lag_168h',
    'price_roll_24h', 'price_roll_168h',
    'hour', 'dayofweek', 'month',
    'solar_load_ratio', 'wind_load_ratio'
]
features = base_features + sentiment_features

# Add lag and rolling features
merged_df['price_lag_1h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(1)
merged_df['price_lag_24h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24)
merged_df['price_lag_168h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(168)
merged_df['price_roll_24h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(24).mean()
merged_df['price_roll_168h'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].rolling(168).mean()

# Calendar and ratio features
merged_df['hour'] = merged_df.index.hour
merged_df['dayofweek'] = merged_df.index.dayofweek
merged_df['month'] = merged_df.index.month
merged_df['solar_load_ratio'] = merged_df['DE_solar_generation_actual'] / merged_df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']
merged_df['wind_load_ratio'] = merged_df['DE_wind_generation_actual'] / merged_df['DE_load_actual_entsoe_transparency']

# Final dataframe
final_df = merged_df[features + ['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].dropna()

# Train-test split
X = final_df[features]
y = final_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)']
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, shuffle=False)

Let me know if you’d like to lag more than one sentiment feature or try different offsets.

You said:
I added more than one lag and rolling averages for the sentiment and it only improved the results slightly, what other things can be done
ChatGPT said:

Nice work experimenting with multiple lags and rolling averages — those are solid starting points for incorporating temporal dynamics. Since you've only seen slight improvements, here are other ideas you can try to boost model performance with the multimodal setup:

🔧 1. Aggregate Sentiment Per Category

You've already selected influential categories. Instead of one avg_score, create separate sentiment scores per top category:

python
# Pivot sentiment features into wide format (date x category)
pivot_df = sentiment_df.pivot_table(
    index='utc_timestamp', 
    columns='category', 
    values='sentiment_score', 
    aggfunc='mean'
)
pivot_df.columns = [f"sentiment_{col}" for col in pivot_df.columns]

Then join it with your energy data. Lagging these category-specific signals could uncover relationships with price shifts.

📆 2. Time-Since-Last-News Feature

Create a feature that counts how many hours passed since the last news headline was published. Could be useful in indicating market attention.

python
sentiment_df['utc_timestamp'] = pd.to_datetime(sentiment_df['utc_timestamp'])
sentiment_df = sentiment_df.sort_values('utc_timestamp')
sentiment_df['hours_since_last_news'] = sentiment_df['utc_timestamp'].diff().dt.total_seconds() / 3600

Then resample it to hourly (using .ffill()), merge it, and maybe apply a cap (e.g., max 12 hours).

🕒 3. Interaction Terms

Create interaction features between structured and unstructured data. Example:

python
merged_df['sentiment_x_solar_ratio'] = merged_df['avg_score_lag_24h'] * merged_df['solar_load_ratio']

Try interactions that make intuitive sense — e.g., positive news sentiment × renewable output.

📉 4. Use Return Instead of Price

Prices may have high autocorrelation and seasonal trends. Try modeling price change (diff) instead:

python
merged_df['price_change'] = merged_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].diff()

Then use price_change as your target instead of raw price. This might highlight the influence of news better.

🔍 5. Try SHAP Again

Use SHAP again on your multimodal model to see how much the new sentiment features contribute. It’ll help justify whether it's worth keeping them or investing in better extraction methods (e.g., classification instead of averaging).

🧠 6. Switch Model Type

Try a recurrent model (LSTM, TCN) or a temporal fusion transformer (TFT) that explicitly models temporal dependencies between structured and unstructured data — especially if you're interested in multi-step forecasts.

📚 7. Use NLP classification instead of sentiment

Instead of using avg_score, train a classifier on the news titles to detect topics like:

  • 📈 energy demand spike

  • 🌤️ weather volatility

  • 🛢️ oil crisis

  • 📉 recession fears

Use the predicted topic probabilities as input features.

Would you like to try one of these together now? I can help you build a version with category-specific sentiment or try interaction terms, for example.

You said:
does xgboost require dropping N/A?
ChatGPT said:

Yes — XGBoost requires you to drop or handle missing (NaN) values in your training and prediction data, but it also has some native support for missing values. Here’s what you need to know:

✅ What You Can Do

1. Drop rows with NaNs (most common & safe)

python
X_train = X_train.dropna()
y_train = y_train.loc[X_train.index]

2. XGBoost can internally handle NaNs (but cautiously)

If you don’t explicitly drop NaNs, XGBoost will treat them as "missing" and learn how to split based on their presence. This works best when:

  • The missingness itself has signal (e.g., no wind data means zero wind).

  • The data is sparse, and the model can infer structure from it.

python
model = XGBRegressor(..., missing=np.nan)  # default behavior

⚠️ But if you feed it a lot of missing values in critical features, or mismatch X and y indices, the performance and stability can suffer.

💡 Best Practice

  • Drop NaNs during model training unless there's a good reason to believe the missingness holds meaning.

  • Use .fillna(0) or .fillna(method='ffill') only when you’re certain that's a sensible substitute.

Want me to help write a safe dropna snippet for your final features and target?

You said:
is there an alogorithm to fill NANs with zeros?
ChatGPT said:

Yes, you can easily fill NaN values with zeros using pandas, and it’s a common and simple imputation method when zeros are a logical substitute (e.g., no production → 0 energy).

✅ Code Example

python
# Fill NaNs with 0s in the feature set
X_filled = X.fillna(0)

If you also want to ensure the target (e.g., price) has no NaNs:

python
y_filled = y.loc[X_filled.index].fillna(0)

⚠️ When is this appropriate?

Use .fillna(0) only when:

  • A missing value means absence (e.g., zero wind means no wind data → 0).

  • The model should learn that no data = no signal.

🧠 Other filling algorithms

If zero isn’t ideal, other strategies include:

  • ffill or bfill: Forward/backward fill based on previous/next value

  • Mean/median fill: X.fillna(X.mean())

  • Interpolation: X.interpolate()

  • Model-based imputation (e.g., KNN, IterativeImputer)

Let me know the context of your missing values and I can help pick the best method. Want to explore that?

You said:
The missing data is the sentiment score
ChatGPT said:

Thanks! Since the missing values are in the sentiment score, here’s how we can think about it and choose a good strategy:

💡 Why is sentiment missing?

In your case, sentiment is missing because:

  • There were no articles published during that hour, or

  • The articles were not in the selected influential categories, or

  • The articles didn’t get processed properly (e.g., NLP didn't run for them)

✅ Best Options for Filling Missing Sentiment Scores

🔹 Option 1: Fill with 0

python
merged_df['avg_score'] = merged_df['avg_score'].fillna(0)

  • Interpretation: No news = Neutral or no effect = 0 sentiment.

  • ✅ Fast and simple

  • ✅ Often works fine with tree-based models like XGBoost

🔹 Option 2: Fill with Daily Mean

python
merged_df['avg_score'] = merged_df['avg_score'].fillna(
    merged_df['avg_score'].rolling(24, min_periods=1).mean()
)

  • Assumes sentiment trend continues even if news is missing

  • Smooths over missing periods but can lag

🔹 Option 3: Forward Fill (propagate last value)

python
merged_df['avg_score'] = merged_df['avg_score'].ffill().fillna(0)

  • Carries over recent sentiment trend

  • Fallback to zero if the beginning of the series has NaNs

🧪 What I'd Recommend You Try First

Since this is for a model input feature, start with:

python
merged_df['avg_score'] = merged_df['avg_score'].fillna(0)

Then later try the rolling mean or forward fill and compare model performance. Want me to help you run a quick comparison of these methods on your model?

You said:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------- ValueError Traceback (most recent call last) Cell In[94], line 51 49 X = final_df[features] 50 y = final_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'] ---> 51 X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, shuffle=False) File c:\Users\iTECH\.julia\conda\3\x86_64\Lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\_param_validation.py:216, in validate_params.<locals>.decorator.<locals>.wrapper(*args, **kwargs) 210 try: 211 with config_context( 212 skip_parameter_validation=( 213 prefer_skip_nested_validation or global_skip_validation 214 ) 215 ): --> 216 return func(*args, **kwargs) 217 except InvalidParameterError as e: 218 # When the function is just a wrapper around an estimator, we allow 219 # the function to delegate validation to the estimator, but we replace 220 # the name of the estimator by the name of the function in the error 221 # message to avoid confusion. 222 msg = re.sub( 223 r"parameter of \w+ must be", 224 f"parameter of {func.__qualname__} must be", 225 str(e), 226 ) ... 2484 "aforementioned parameters.".format(n_samples, test_size, train_size) 2485 ) 2487 return n_train, n_test ValueError: With n_samples=0, test_size=0.2 and train_size=None, the resulting train set will be empty. Adjust any of the aforementioned parameters. Output is truncated. View as a scrollable element or open in a text editor. Adjust cell output settings...
ChatGPT said:

This error means your final_df is completely empty after .dropna(), so X and y have 0 rows — which makes splitting impossible.

Let’s figure out why final_df ended up empty. Here’s what to do:

✅ Step 1: Check how many rows before and after dropping NaNs

Right before the line that builds final_df, add:

python
print("Before dropna:", merged_df[features + ['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].shape)
print("Missing values per column:")
print(merged_df[features + ['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].isna().sum())

That will show:

  • How many rows your DataFrame has

  • Which columns have missing data (likely the avg_score)

✅ Step 2: Fill sentiment NaNs before .dropna()

If avg_score is the issue, make sure you do this before final_df = ...dropna():

python
merged_df['avg_score'] = merged_df['avg_score'].fillna(0)

Then rerun the final few lines:

python
final_df = merged_df[features + ['Price (EUR/MWhe)']].dropna()
X = final_df[features]
y = final_df['Price (EUR/MWhe)']
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, shuffle=False)

Let me know what the output is from Step 1 and I can guide you further.

You said:
Lets roll way back, what are things that affect energy prices
ChatGPT said:

Great question — rolling back to the fundamentals is always a good move when things get complex.

💡 Main Factors That Affect Energy Prices

Here’s a breakdown of the key variables that influence energy prices, especially electricity:

🏭 Supply-Side Factors

FactorExplanation
Fuel PricesPrices of natural gas, oil, and coal directly impact energy costs — most conventional power plants run on these.
Renewable ProductionSolar and wind output reduce reliance on costly fuels. Their variability (sunlight, wind) introduces price swings.
Energy MixThe proportion of renewables vs fossil fuels affects stability and cost.
Generation CapacityMore available generation (especially from low-cost sources) puts downward pressure on prices.
Outages / MaintenanceScheduled or unplanned plant shutdowns can reduce supply and increase prices.

⚡️ Demand-Side Factors

FactorExplanation
Electricity DemandHigh demand = high prices. Demand varies daily (e.g., mornings, evenings) and seasonally (e.g., winters/summers).
Weather & TemperatureHeat increases cooling demand; cold increases heating. Both spike demand.
Economic ActivityIndustrial and commercial use increases with economic growth.
Population GrowthMore people = higher demand over time.

🌍 External & Market Factors

FactorExplanation
Geopolitical EventsWars, embargoes, or political instability (e.g., in oil-producing countries) disrupt fuel supply chains.
Energy PoliciesCarbon taxes, green energy incentives, and regulations all impact prices.
Market DesignPricing mechanisms (spot market, bidding, auctions) influence volatility.
Currency Exchange RatesIf fuels are imported, currency fluctuations affect costs.

📰 Sentiment / News

FactorExplanation
Energy NewsNews on supply shocks, policy changes, or global events can move markets.
Speculation & FuturesTraders' expectations based on sentiment or forecasts can temporarily move prices.

If you’re forecasting energy prices, it’s smart to include as many of these as you can quantify — especially those that vary hourly or daily.

Would you like me to suggest features you can build based on these factors for your forecasting model?

You said:
Other than news what is a non-numeric input that can be numerically computated
ChatGPT said:

Excellent follow-up 🔍

Beyond news, there are several non-numeric (qualitative/categorical or symbolic) inputs that can meaningfully impact energy prices — and can be converted into numeric features for modeling. Here are a few powerful ones:

🗓️ Calendar & Time-Based Categorical Features

FeatureWhy it MattersHow to Encode
Day of WeekPrices tend to be lower on weekends, higher on weekdays.One-hot encode or integer map (0=Monday, ..., 6=Sunday)
Hour of DayPeak/off-peak consumption hours vary.Integer (0–23), or cyclic transformation (e.g., sin/cos of hour)
Public HolidaysReduced industrial activity and demand.Binary flag or lookup by date
SeasonHeating/cooling demand shifts in winter/summer.Map month → season or use sine/cosine of month

🏛️ Policy or Regulatory Events (Categorical)

FeatureWhy it MattersHow to Encode
Carbon pricing implementationAffects cost of fossil fuel-based power generation.Binary flag or encoded as an index
Subsidy changes for renewablesCan change the supply side dynamics.Binary or time-based flag
Grid operator alert levelsAlerts like scarcity warnings or demand response can affect prices.One-hot or ordinal encoding

🗺️ Geographic or Locational Context

FeatureWhy it MattersHow to Encode
Region/Zone/MarketDifferent prices and regulations per market.One-hot or label encoding
Transmission CongestionCertain zones may have bottlenecks that affect price.Use congestion flags or scores from grid data

📦 Categorical Weather Conditions

FeatureWhy it MattersHow to Encode
Weather Conditions (Sunny, Rainy, Snowy)Affects solar/wind output and demand.One-hot encode weather condition
Cloud Cover TypeImpacts solar production differently than clear skies.Ordinal (e.g., Clear=0, Partly Cloudy=1, Overcast=2)

📣 Event-Based Inputs (Non-News)

EventWhy it MattersHow to Encode
Major Sports EventsCan impact local energy demand (viewing hours).Binary per known event time
Power Grid Maintenance SchedulesTemporary reductions in supply.Flags derived from public grid data
Strikes or ProtestsCould impact industrial demand or fuel supply.Binary temporal flags or counts

⛽ Symbolic Market Events

FeatureWhy it MattersHow to Encode
Oil Inventory ReportsAffect future energy expectations.NLP sentiment score or change direction (↑/↓)
OPEC DecisionsDirectly affect oil supply and thus electricity pricing.Map date of decision → binary/event signal

🧠 Next-Level Idea: "Event embeddings"

Instead of manually encoding events, modern models like transformers can learn embeddings of symbolic data — e.g., using:

  • Pretrained calendar embeddings

  • Learnable policy impact vectors

  • Vectorized symbolic sequences (like weather conditions over 3 days)

Would you like me to help you engineer or simulate one of these into your model (e.g., categorical weather or calendar features)?

You said:
How can I calculate the accuracy of my result
ChatGPT said:

Great question — and it depends a bit on what you're predicting.

Since you're forecasting energy prices (a regression task), you can’t calculate “accuracy” in the traditional classification sense. Instead, you use regression metrics to measure how close your predictions are to the actual values.

✅ Common Regression Metrics for Energy Price Forecasting

MetricMeaningUsefulness
MAE (Mean Absolute Error)Average absolute difference between predicted and actual pricesEasy to interpret, in same units as price
RMSE (Root Mean Squared Error)Penalizes larger errors more than MAEGood when large errors are especially bad
MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error)Error as a % of the actual valueUseful for comparing across different price scales
R² Score (Coefficient of Determination)How much variance your model explains (0 to 1, or negative)Good overall fit indicator

🧪 Example Code

Here’s how you can compute them in Python using sklearn:

python
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error, mean_squared_error, r2_score

# y_test: actual values
# y_pred: predicted values

mae = mean_absolute_error(y_test, y_pred)
rmse = mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred, squared=False)
r2 = r2_score(y_test, y_pred)

print(f"MAE:  {mae:.2f}")
print(f"RMSE: {rmse:.2f}")
print(f"R²:   {r2:.3f}")

Optional (if you want percentage-based error):

python
mape = (abs((y_test - y_pred) / y_test)).mean() * 100
print(f"MAPE: {mape:.2f}%")

⚠️ Note: MAPE is sensitive to zeros in actual values (division by zero), so use with caution if energy prices ever hit 0.

If you show me your latest prediction and ground truth, I can compute these for you! Or if you're using a notebook, I can generate a final evaluation cell for you. Want that?

You said:
can i do rolling average from time t-48 to t-24?
ChatGPT said:

Yes, you absolutely can compute a rolling average from time t−48 to t−24 — this is often referred to as a lagged rolling window or a delayed moving average.

🧠 Why It's Useful

Instead of using the most recent values (which may cause data leakage in forecasting), you’re using past values with a buffer — in this case, a window that ends at t-24 and starts at t-48.

✅ Code Example in Pandas

python
# Assume `df` has a datetime index and a column 'Price (EUR/MWhe)'

# Shift the series 24 steps back to exclude the most recent 24 hours
lagged_series = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24)

# Apply a rolling average over the 24-hour window from t-48 to t-24
df['price_roll_t48_t24'] = lagged_series.rolling(window=24).mean()

🔁 What's Happening?

At time t, this value will be:

css
mean(Price[t-48], Price[t-47], ..., Price[t-25])

The shift(24) ensures you're excluding the last 24 hours (t-24 to t) from the window, and the .rolling(24).mean() grabs the 24 points before that (t-48 to t-25).

Would you like to generate multiple of these rolling features at different lag intervals (like t−72 to t−48, etc.)?

You said:
yes please for t-72, t-48, t-168,
ChatGPT said:

Great! Here's a clean block of code that computes lagged rolling averages for these three intervals:

  • t-72 to t-48

  • t-48 to t-24

  • t-168 to t-72

Each window skips the most recent data to avoid leakage and gives you different historical summaries to feed into your model.

✅ Code to Add Lagged Rolling Averages

python
# Assume df has datetime index and column 'Price (EUR/MWhe)'

# t-72 to t-48
df['price_roll_t72_t48'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(48).rolling(window=24).mean()

# t-48 to t-24
df['price_roll_t48_t24'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(24).rolling(window=24).mean()

# t-168 to t-72
df['price_roll_t168_t72'] = df['Price (EUR/MWhe)'].shift(72).rolling(window=96).mean()

📌 Add These to Your Feature List

Once you've added these to your DataFrame, just update your features list:

python
features += ['price_roll_t72_t48', 'price_roll_t48_t24', 'price_roll_t168_t72']

Want the same approach for other features like temperature or renewables too?

ChatGPT said:

That error typically happens when one of your inputs (X_train or y_train) is not formatted correctly — usually because X_train is not a clean DataFrame with only numerical columns, or it contains missing values or unexpected objects like strings, datetime, or even entire DataFrames.

✅ Here's how to fix it:

Add the following diagnostic block right before model.fit(...):

python
# Check for non-numeric columns
print("Non-numeric columns in X_train:")
print(X_train.select_dtypes(exclude=['number']).columns)

# Check for NaNs
print("\nMissing values in X_train:", X_train.isnull().sum().sum())
print("Missing values in y_train:", y_train.isnull().sum())

# Optional: convert X_train to numeric if needed
# X_train = X_train.apply(pd.to_numeric, errors='coerce')

# Drop any remaining rows with NaNs
X_train = X_train.dropna()
y_train = y_train.loc[X_train.index]  # Align y to X after dropping

Then retry:

python
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

✅ Fix: Remove one of them.

2. Missing Columns in DataFrame

If any of the features listed in features are not properly computed or spelled wrong, they’ll cause KeyError when slicing merged_df.

✅ Check: After feature engineering, add this before creating final_df:

python
print("Available columns:", merged_df.columns)
print("Missing from merged_df:", [f for f in features if f not in merged_df.columns])

3. Non-numeric Types

Ensure none of the features contain non-numeric values (e.g., strings or datetime objects). XGBoost expects only numeric inputs.

✅ Check:

python
print(X.dtypes[X.dtypes != 'float64'])

4. NaNs Before Drop

Before calling .dropna(), you might want to inspect how many missing values are in each feature:

python

python
missing = [col for col in features if col not in merged_df.columns]
print("🚨 Missing columns in merged_df:", missing)

This will list any features that weren’t actually created.

print("✅ Final features in final_df:", final_df.columns.tolist())
